From files.usgwarchives.net/ny/suffolk/obits/nd/2005/feb/nd20f... Raffell, Rodd RAFFELL-Rodd, of Oceanside, New York, on February 15, 2005, one month shy of his ninety-first birthday. Despite recent failing health, Mr. Raffell still wrote and arranged and lead a 26-piece concert jazz orchestra. He has been associated with such big bands as Charlie Spivak, Sammy Kaye, Jimmy Dorsey and Stan Kenton. Rodd Raffell also fronted his own big bands, which were well established in the mid-western states, prior to moving to Long Island. He leaves behind beloved daughters, Jamie Raffell and Myrna Berrios of Oceanside. A Memorial Service will be held at Malverne Funeral Home, 330 Hempstead Ave., Malverne, Tuesday evening, February 22, from 7-9 PM (516-593-7230). Published in Newsday on 2/20/2005.

This is Mary Boomer Page, a Chicago-based educator who led summer tours of Europe for educators. c. 1907. Mary Boomer Page was a member of the Chicago local board of the International Kindergartners' Union in 1901, according to the New York Tribune (11 April 1901). She also served on the Finance Committee of the Union, and as president of the Kindergarten Literature Company. She was a resident director at the Gertrude House settlement, which was in turn the location of the Chicago Kindergarten Institute.

May 2, 1914 was declared "woman suffrage day" and parades and meetings were held in almost every state. See memory.loc.gov/ammem/collections/suffrage/nwp/brftime.html and NYT editorial from May 2, 1914 supporting the effort query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0DE2D9153AE733A... Dr. D. M. Dunn was head of the women's department of the Life Extension Institute.  She also served on the executive committee of the German-American Suffrage Association in the 1910s.  Dunn was a proponent of moderate corseting, and regular exercise for women.
books.google.com/books?id=IohLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA122&l... is a 1921 article by her in The Woman's Journal and books.google.com/books?id=U7A8AAAAMAAJ&pg=RA5-PA20&am... is another in The Literary Digest.

Here's the link about her ideas on corseting (but to answer your question, both! She considered exercise important, but thought a well-made moderate "low" corset was preferable to no corset, if a woman had bad posture; but heavy, badly-made corsets were still harmful). Maude Malone organized the Harlem Equal Rights League in 1905.  She was known for being a loud protester, shouting questions during politicians' speeches.

According to www.jstor.org/pss/25542770 Libraries & Culture © 1995 "The Library Employees' Union, founded in 1917 in New York City, was the first union of public library workers in the United States. A major focus of the union was the inferior status of women library workers and their low salaries. The union's main spokesperson, Maud Malone, had been active in the reinvigoration of the women's suffrage movement that occurred in the first decade of the twentieth century. Advocating the affiliation of library workers with women's organizations and with the working class, the union applied the tactics used by suffragists and other reformers to the library world. "
Oh cool, she was a librarian!  Somehow makes wonderful sense for her to turn up in the Commons, then. ;)

Reno (Nevada) Evening Gazette - April 29, 1914

SOCIALISTS ARE JAILED

Make Demonstrastion in Front of Rocefeller Offices in New York

NEW YORK, April 29 -- Upton Sinclair, his wife and three other women, were arrested today for a demonstration in front of the offices of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., in the Standard Oil Building.
The prisoners were taken to the Old Slip Police Sationwhere Mrs. Sinclait was released. The other women who were placed in cells pending their arraignment in court, said they were Mrs. Emmeline Pankhurst, Mrs Margaret Remington Charter  and Mrs. Donie Leitner. All had been arrested on the sidewalk in front of 26 Broadway.
A woman who said she was a socialist, invaded the outer offices of Mr. Rockefeller and sought an interviewn withy him in reference to the coal miners' strike in Colorado. Rockefeller's secretary told her he was busy at a conference.
The woman carried an American flag into the office and described herself as Mrs. Belle N. Zilverman.
She was joined on the sidewalk by Upton Sinclair, who wore a bit of crepe on his arm in pursuance of a plan announced at a Socialist mass meeting last night, where it was agreed "that mourners" should gather in front of the Standard Oil Building as a protest against conditions in Colorado. Mrs. Zilverman and Upton were the first to arrive on the scene.
Mrs. Zilverman sought to place this message befopre the younger Rockefeller:
"I am an American citizen standing before your door, waiting for just a word with you. Will you grant me this request? My question will be brief and to the point."
All the prisoners were charged with disorderly conduct, and in a patrol wagon were taken to the Tombs police court. Mrs. Leitner said she was an artiist and her home was in Georgia.
While her husband was still locked up, Mrs. Sinclair returned to the scene of the arrests and began pacing slowly back and forth in front of the big building. She wore a white polo coat, the left sleeve of which bore a strip of crepe. Half a dozen men, all wearing crepe, walked with or near her. Perhaps 500 persons paused to witness the sight, but for the time being police made no arrests. 
Mr. Rockefeller remained secluded in his private office on the fourteenth floor of the building.
26 Broadway (on banner with skull and crossbones is the address of the Standard Oil building and where John D. Rockefeller had his offices.

This IWW rally in Mulberry Park was mentioned in NYT of May 2, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CE3D9153AE733A... in lefthand column of second page. The previous day, Marie Ganz had forced her way into the Standard Oil building, as reported in NYT of May 1, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9405E1DE173AE633A...
A few years later she wrote a memoir, Rebels; Into Anarchy--and Out Again lccn.loc.gov/20000219
Berkman is Alexander Berkman.

Mulberry Park (the term used by the New York Times), also called Mulberry Bend Park, was built on the site of Mulberry Bend, the slum location exposed for its inhuman and wretched conditions of disease, filth and crime by the reformer (and photographer) Jacob Riis. The demolition of these slums and the building of the park were crusades championed by Riis. His account of the conditions and the building of the park (completed in 1897) is a bit long-winded, but still fascinating: "The Bend is laid by the Heels" www.bartleby.com/207/11.html No doubt Mulberry Bend Park's history made it an ideal place to rally May Day marchers by the Anarchists of the day, like Berkman and Ganz. From there, as the Times article cited above recounts, they marched uptown to Union Square where a sort of melee ensued. The Times' coverage is very colorful, though it seems unnecessarily Runyonesque and a bit condescending as well. Mulberry Bend Park had been renamed Columbus Park in 1911, though neither Bain nor the Times referred to it as such in 1914. Old habits die hard. www.nycgovparks.org/parks/M015/highlights/6430 A useful overview of the main characters and events of Spring, 1914 (of which the Bain Collection has many pictures) can be found at: userwww.sfsu.edu/~jmmoran/edelsohn.htm

Marie Ganz did indeed go on to write a memoir entitled " Rebel Into Anarchy and out Again"  which she co-wrote  with Nat J. Ferber whom she later married and had a daughter Lenore Ferber Kahn my mother-in-law.

Mrs WJ Gaynor , at this stage the widow of the mayor of New York City who had died in September 1913, was the former Augusta Cole Mayer. see books.google.com/books?id=WN90SSAJ4JMC&pg=PA28&lp... A society register of 1912 indicates names for three of their eight children: Helen, Norman, and Rufus. The Bain photo, dated April 21, celebrates a happy event that took place on April 16, 1914 -- the wedding of the late mayor's son, Norman J. Gaynor, to Betsy Page. The ceremony took place in Fairfax Court House, Virginia. The photo of the wedding attendees (likely posed at the railroad station in New York City) may have been taken upon their return. Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont was a prominent suffrage leader. She wrote a suffrage operetta called "Melinda and Her Sisters." Additionally, she was an early advocate for equal pay for equal work, regardless of gender.

Mrs. Belmont was also known for "good works" donating time and money to hospitals etc. One of her famous quotes: "The term 'idle rich' is certainly a misnomer now if it ever had a foundation in fact."

Mrs. Belmont's husband, Oliver Hazard Perry Belmont, was a grandson of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry, whose U. S. Navy squadron defeated a British fleet in the Battle of Lake Erie, during the War of 1812.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alva_Belmont Alva Erskine Belmont (January 17, 1853 – January 26, 1933), née Alva Erskine Smith, also called from 1875 to 1896) Alva Vanderbilt, was a prominent multi-millionaire American socialite and a major figure in the women's suffrage movement. Known for having an aristocratic manner that antagonized many people, she was also noted for her energy, intelligence, strong opinions, and willingness to challenge convention. She was married first to William Kissam Vanderbilt, with whom she had three children, and secondly to Oliver Hazard Perry Belmont. She died on 26 January 1933 in Paris, France.

I found it interesting that there was no other info about who this was other than "Sickles," so a quick Internet search found the following:  (from Wikipedia)

(Daniel) Sickles lived out the remainder of his life in New York City, dying on May 3, 1914. His funeral was held at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan on May 8, 1914. He was buried in Arlington National Cemetery.

Daniel Edgar Sickles (October 20, 1819 – May 3, 1914) was a colorful and controversial American politician, Union general in the American Civil War, and diplomat.

As an antebellum New York politician, Sickles was involved in a number of public scandals, most notably the killing of his wife's lover, Philip Barton Key II, son of Francis Scott Key. He was acquitted with the first use of temporary insanity as a legal defense in U.S. history. He became one of the most prominent political generals of the Civil War. At the Battle of Gettysburg, he insubordinately moved his III Corps to a position in which it was virtually destroyed, an action that continues to generate controversy. His combat career ended at Gettysburg when his leg was struck by cannon fire.
The man leading the procession (carrying Gen. Sickles' hat and saber) looks familiar, maybe from earlier Bain photos.  My best guess is Elihu Root, then a senator from New York.  Anyone else??

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM COMPANY:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM COMPANY:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

Since March 19, 1914 Norhtern Division comanded by Francisco Villa, approached Laguna District by Conejos rail road station, some kilometers north of Gomez Palacio (In fact you can read in American newspapers of those dates, that Gómez Palacio is a suburb of Torreón [which is not.  It's a city in Durango State just separated from Torreón by Nazas River]).  The artillery was used to shell heavily that city between days 28th and 30th.  So "near Torreón" means that the cannon is located in the northern outskirts of Gómez Palacio, unless the photo was taken between March 31st and April 1st, the the gun is in the southern outskirts of Gómez Palacio, facing towards Torreón, by Nazas River which in that district is the divisory line between both cities and the States of Coahuila and Durango.

Patterson's American education, Volume 59, which looks to have been published in 1962 indicates that the Metropolitan Vocational High School was at 78 Catharine [sic] St, New York, NY. Catherine St. is on the Lower East Side, not far from the Brooklyn Bridge.

NYT of March 23, 1969 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20D11FA3A5D137A... {needs subscription} reported that the Board of Education was closing the "32-year-old Metropolitan Vocational High School on the Lower East Side." The address was given as 78 Catherine Street. By that time, the music program shown in these pictures had moved to the High School for the Performing Arts which was apparently a branch of Metropolitan Vocational High, according to NYT of May 29, 1955 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0916FB345A1B7B... NYT of April 12, 1949 indicates the same relationship and gives the address of the School of Performing Arts as 120 West 46th Street.

The article Gottlieb did for Down Beat [ hdl.loc.gov/loc.music/wgpubs.093 ] described the school as "a beat up school in Lower Manhattan, just off the fringes of Chinatown." That argues for these pictures being taken at the 78 Catherine St. location.

USS New York (Battleship # 34, later BB-34), 1914-1948 USS New York, lead ship of a two-ship class of 27,000-ton battleships, was built at the New York Navy Yard. Commissioned in April 1914, her first active service was off Vera Cruz, Mexico, during the U.S. intervention there. After more than three years of operations off the east coast and in the Caribbean, in December 1917 New York crossed the Atlantic to join the British Grand Fleet. She was flagship of the U.S. battleships of the Sixth Battle Squadron during the remainder of the First World War. In mid-1919, New York transited the Panama Canal to the Pacific, where she was based during the next decade and a half. As a unit of the Battle Fleet, she took an active part in the exercises, drills and gunnery practices that were regularly held in the Pacific and Caribbean. New York underwent modernization in 1925-27, receiving new oil-fired boilers, anti-torpedo bulges on her hull sides, heavier deck armor, up-to-date gunfire control mechanisms and many other improvements that enhanced her combat capabilities. After being transferred to the Atlantic in the mid-1930s, she visited England in 1937 as the U.S. representative to the British Coronation naval review. Over the next three years, the battleship was actively employed as a training ship. With the coming of war to Europe, New York participated in Neutrality Patrol operations, and, as the U.S. drew closer to the conflict in 1941, helped in the occupation of Iceland and in escorting convoys. Her convoy activities continued after the United States became a combatant in December 1941. In November 1942, New York also took part the North African invasion, providing gunfire support for landings at Safi, Morocco. She spent 1943 and most of 1944 on escort and training duties, steaming to the Pacific war zone in early 1945. In February, New York's big guns were active bombarding Iwo Jima before and during the Marines' assault on that island. She was similarly employed off Okinawa from late March until June, and was lightly damaged by a suicide plane on 14 April 1945. Following the Japanese capitulation in August 1945, New York moved back to the Atlantic and was at New York City for the Navy Day fleet review in late October. Her last active service was as a target during the atomic bomb tests at Bikini, Marshall Islands, in July 1946. Too radioactive and far too old for further use, she decommissioned a month later. In July 1948, USS New York was towed out to sea off Pearl Harbor and sunk as a target for Navy aircraft and ships. www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-n/bb34.htm

Emil Abderhalden (March 9, 1877 – August 5, 1950) was a Swiss biochemist and physiologist. His main findings, though disputed already in the 1920s, were not finally rejected until the late 1990s. Whether his misleading findings were based on fraud or simply the result of a lack of scientific rigor remains unclear. Abderhalden's drying pistol, used in chemistry, was first described by one of his students in a textbook Abderhalden edited. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emil_Abderhalden

Alfred Deakin (3 August 1856 – 7 October 1919), Australian politician, was a leader of the movement for Australian federation and later the second Prime Minister of Australia. In the last quarter of the nineteenth century, Deakin was a major contributor to the establishment of liberal reforms in the colony of Victoria, including the protection of rights at work. He also played a major part in establishing irrigation in Australia. It is likely that he could have been Premier of Victoria, but he chose to devote his energy to federation. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Deakin

The Vaterland sailed for Hamburg from New York harbor in May, 1914, with the newlywed Liggetts (tobacco heirs) aboard:

LIGGETT WEDDED SECRETLY
The New York Times | May 28, 1914 
  
Sailed with Bride, Who Was Violet Colby, Actress, on the Vaterland 

It became known yesterday that I among those whose names were not printed on the passenger list of the Vaterland of the Hamburg-American Line when she sailed on Tuesday morning for Hamburg were John E. Liggett of St. Louis and his bride; Violet Colby, an actress, who recently divorced Clarence Harvey, a comedian. Mr. Liggett, who is wealthy, a month ago paid for a suite consisting of two rooms and bath and requested that the name be kept off the list.

Friends of both Mr. and Mrs. Liggett yesterday said there had been a rumors circulated that they had been married in Asheville, N. C., early in April, but no confirmation could be obtained except that the couple sailed on the Vaterland as Mr. and Mrs. Liggett.

Mrs. Harvey's decree was confirmed by the Supreme Court of New York in January last, and the first Mrs. Liggett obtained hers in March, with the custody of two children.

Mrs. Harvey has been living at the Belnord a at Eighty-sixth Street and Broadway, and before her trunks were sent away on Monday she contradicted reports that she was engaged to marry Mr. Liggett or any other man.

Hermann Paasche ( February 24, 1851, Burg bei Magdeburg – April 11, 1925, Detroit) was a German statistician and economist. He is known for his Paasche Index, which provides a calculation of the Price Index. Paasche studied economics, agriculture, statistics and philosophy at University of Halle. In 1879, he became a professor of political science at Aachen University of Technology. Paasche died in 1925 in Detroit, Michigan, United States. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann_Paasche

When I saw Nemours I thought this must have something to do with DuPont and Delaware. According to this old book on trapshooting the Nemours Gun Club was the first women's trapshooting club in the United States, founded in Wilmington, Delaware in 1913.
Here's an article from the DuPont Magazine about the club digital.hagley.org/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/p15017coll... It's on page 29 (I don't think you can link directly to the page)

They probably shot with DuPont Powders, too (the brand made famous by the "DuPont Dogs":
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/shookphotos/4726667357/]
"In 1913 Mrs. Harriet Hammond organized the Nemours Gun Club, for women trapshooters, the first women's shooting club in America."   The Great Delaware Sports Book by Doug Gelbert

From Her Best Shot: Women and Guns in America by Laura Browder (UNC Press 2006), p 71:
"An employee in the agricultural division of Du Pont, Hammond had suggested that the company offer shooting classes especially for women as part of its gun club. The classes went so well that a trapshooting club for women was established. An adjunct of the Du Pont Trapshooting Club, the women's group was allowed to use the traps one afternoon a week, since 'it was not feasible to give up one of [the main club's] traps to women on regular shooting days.'"

Major-General Alexander Augustus Frederick William Alfred George Cambridge, 1st Earl of Athlone KG GCB GCMG GCVO DSO PC ADC(P) FRS (born Prince Alexander of Teck; 14 April 1874 – 16 January 1957), was a close relative of the shared British and Canadian royal family, as well as a British military commander and major-general who served as Governor-General of the Union of South Africa, the country's fourth, and as Governor General of Canada, the 16th since Canadian Confederation. Prince Alexander was born in London, United Kingdom, to the Duke and Duchess of Teck, and was educated at Eton College before moving on to Sandhurst for training as an officer. He rose in rank through his service in African campaigns and the First World War, receiving numerous honours and decorations, including elevation to the peerage as the Earl of Athlone, after he relinquished his German title of Prince of Teck in the Kingdom of Württemberg. He was in 1927 appointed as South Africa's governor general by George V, King of the United Kingdom, on the recommendation of Prime Minister of the United Kingdom Stanley Baldwin, to replace Prince Arthur of Connaught as viceroy, and he occupied the post until succeeded by the Earl of Clarendon in 1930. Athlone then served as Chancellor of the University of London until he was in 1940 appointed as Canada's governor general by George VI, king of Canada, on the recommendation of Prime Minister of Canada William Lyon Mackenzie King, to replace the Lord Tweedsmuir as viceroy, and he occupied the post until succeeded by the Viscount Alexander of Tunis in 1946. Athlone proved to be instrumental in the Canadian war effort and as a host to British and American statesmen during the Second World War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Cambridge,_1st_Earl_of_At... John Buchan, 1st Baron Tweedsmuir GCMG GCVO CH PC (26 August 1875 – 11 February 1940) was a Scottish novelist and Unionist politician who served as Governor General of Canada, the 15th since Canadian Confederation. After a brief career in law, Buchan simultaneously began writing and his political and diplomatic career, serving as a private secretary to the colonial administrator of various colonies in Southern Africa, and eventually wrote propaganda for the British war effort in First World War. Once back in civilian life, Buchan was elected Member of Parliament for the Combined Scottish Universities, but spent most of his time on his writing career. He wrote The Thirty-Nine Steps and other adventure fiction. He was in 1935 appointed as governor general by George V, king of Canada, on the recommendation of Prime Minister of Canada Richard Bennett, to replace the Earl of Bessborough as viceroy, and occupied that post until his death in 1940. Buchan proved to be enthusiastic about literacy, as well as the evolution of Canadian culture, and he received a state funeral in Canada before his ashes were returned to the UK and interred at Elsfield, Oxfordshire.

"During the Mexican Revolution the United States, fearing for its interest in the Gulf of Mexico, captured the port of Vera Cruz during April, 1914. This act placed the two countries at the brink of war, creating a considerable amount of international tension. Agentina, Brazil and Chile offered to mediate the dispute and their offer was accepted by the Mexican and American governments. Niagara Falls was selected as the location for the peace conference, with the meetings taking place at the Clifton House Hotel, now the site of Oakes Garden Theatre. The talks began on May 20. After about a month, an agreement was reached that averted a war between Mexico and the United States. However, Mexico's internal strife continued. On Sunday, May 24, shortly after the conference had opened, all the delegates and their families, along with many local residents and members of the press, attended a special peace mass at Our Lady of Peace. It was a proud and significant day for Our Lady of Peace." carmelnet.org/olp/olp.htm

Mary Harris "Mother" Jones (August 1, 1837 – November 30, 1930), born in Cork, Ireland, was a prominent American labor and community organizer, who helped co-ordinate major strikes and co-founded the Industrial Workers of the World. She worked as a teacher and dressmaker but after her husband and four children all died of yellow fever and her workshop was destroyed in a fire in 1871 she began working as an organizer for the Knights of Labor and the United Mine Workers union. She was a very effective speaker, punctuating her speeches with stories, audience participation, humour and dramatic stunts. From 1897 (when she was 60) she was known as Mother Jones and in 1902 she was called "the most dangerous woman in America" for her success in organizing mine workers and their families against the mine owners. In 1903, upset about the lax enforcement of the child labour laws in the Pennsylvania mines and silk mills, she organized a Children's March from Philadelphia to the home of then president Theodore Roosevelt in New York. The magazine Mother Jones , established in 1970, is named after her. In the 1989-90 Pittston Coal strike the wives and daughters of the miners organised themselves as the "Daughters of Mother Jones" and represented the strikers to the press. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Harris_Jones

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Proctor_Gould_Harding William Proctor Gould Harding (May 5, 1864 – April 7, 1930) was an American banker. He was born in Boligee, Alabama, and graduated from the University of Alabama in 1881. He was the second Chairman of the Federal Reserve, serving from 1916 to 1922. After working in Cuba to reorganize the financial System, he was appointed president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston in 1923 and served until his death in 1930. His death was due to heart trouble after a long illness. He died at his Boston home. His obituary was printed in the New York Times, April 8, 1930. [1] He also served as the managing director of the War Finance Corporation.

We appreciate the identification of William P. G. Harding and his link to the Federal Reserve Board. We will add some of the information to the description when we update. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw George Bernard Shaw (26 July 1856 – 2 November 1950)[1] was an Irish playwright and a co-founder of the London School of Economics. Although his first profitable writing was music and literary criticism, in which capacity he wrote many highly articulate pieces of journalism, his main talent was for drama, and he wrote more than 60 plays. Nearly all his writings deal sternly with prevailing social problems, but have a vein of comedy to make their stark themes more palatable. Shaw examined education, marriage, religion, government, health care, and class privilege.
Thank you Richard Arthur Norton.  We will add more information about playwright George Bernard Shaw and the fuller form of his name when we update the database.

He would have been in the news around this time for at least two reasons. His Pygmalion (on which My Fair Lady is based) opened in London in April 1914. Shaw also wrote frequently about the war (or his ideas as to how to achieve peace) in Europe. For example, on November 15, 1914, an article by Shaw was published in the NYT. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05EFD8153FE233A... Site of the 1914 Niagara Falls peace conference. From carmelnet.org/olp/olp.htm "During the Mexican Revolution the United States, fearing for its interest in the Gulf of Mexico, captured the port of Vera Cruz during April, 1914. This act placed the two countries at the brink of war, creating a considerable amount of international tension. Agentina, Brazil and Chile offered to mediate the dispute and their offer was accepted by the Mexican and American governments. Niagara Falls was selected as the location for the peace conference, with the meetings taking place at the Clifton House Hotel, now the site of Oakes Garden Theatre. The talks began on May 20. After about a month, an agreement was reached that averted a war between Mexico and the United States. However, Mexico's internal strife continued. On Sunday, May 24, shortly after the conference had opened, all the delegates and their families, along with many local residents and members of the press, attended a special peace mass at Our Lady of Peace. It was a proud and significant day for Our Lady of Peace." According to www.cliftonhill.com/attractions/niagara-parks/oakes-garde... the Oakes Garden Theatre "is the entranceway to Queen Victoria Park, Niagara Parks' centerpiece that showcases the Falls. " and was built in 1936 (presumably demolishing the hotel in this Bain photo, if it hadn't been taken down earlier).
Thanks swanq for the information about the Clifton Hotel and its role in the 1914 Niagara Falls peace conference.  We will add some of it to the description when we update.

I started an article on the conference in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABC_Conference The ABC Conference started on May 20, 1914, when the the ABC Powers met in Niagara Falls, Canada, to mediate diplomatically in order to avoid war between the United States and Mexico after increasing tensions over the Tampico Affair and the United States occupation of Veracruz, and the issues that led to the Mexican Revolution. At the conference, the United States was represented by Frederick William Lehmann, a former United States Solicitor General, and Joseph Rucker Lamar, an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. I also started a biography of Romulo S. Naon: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romulo_S._Naon

This appears to be a misidentification (probably due to the original caption being cut off at the bottom of the photo) by the folks at Bain. This is not Lieut. "F.H. Lacy", but Lieut. L.H. Lacy. Lt. Lindsay Hensley Lacy (USN) was a 1903 graduate of the Naval Academy at Annapolis, and contemporary accounts (1913 Annual Report of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society) describe him as an aid to Admiral Cameron McR Winslow (who is featured in a number of Bain/LOC photos). The same Lindsay H. Lacy would be listed years later as a member of the English Department faculty at Louisiana State University (LSU) in the 1930s and 1940s.

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM COMPANY:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting.

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution.

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

www.jstor.org/pss/2187079 indicates that he was a former Mexican Ambassador to the U.S. -- former in April 1912. He is not listed at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ambassadors_of_Mexico_to_t... From an auction notice: www.dsloan.com/Auctions/A21/item-chamizal_arbitration-cas... "The Last Great Texas Land Dispute 33. CHAMIZAL ARBITRATION. CASASUS, Joaquín D[emetrio]. El Chamizal: Demanda, réplica, alegato é informes presentados por el Licenciado Joaquín D. Casasus ante el tribunal de arbitraje y sentencia pronunciada por el mismo tribunal. Mexico: Eusebio Gómez de la Puente, Editor, 1911. 656, [4] pp. 4to (24 x 17 cm.), original grey printed wrappers. Light wear and foxing to fragile wraps, interior fine, unopened. Contemporary ink signature of Sr. Lic. Rafael P. Garcia, 2a San José 3 Puebla. Uncommon, even in institutional holdings. First edition. Porrúa 47115. This work is a collection of the presentations made by Joaquín D. Casasus to the arbitration panel charged with deciding the Chamizal dispute and is considered his finest legal effort. Because of his arguments, Mexico was awarded a substantial part of the disputed area, although the United States refused to recognize the arbitrators’ findings. The dispute arose because the Rio Grande river channel shifted significantly in 1864, placing in Texas about 600 acres of formerly Mexican territory as awarded in the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo (among the historical arguments cited is the Disturnell Treaty map). As generally understood, the Treaty allowed the border to shift with the Rio Grande, so long as the shift was gradual and caused by silting and other slow-acting factors. The arbitration panel was convened by both countries to decide the matter. Despite their ruling, the dispute was not totally solved until 1963, when President Kennedy agreed to the original arbitration findings. Handbook of Texas Online: Chamizal Dispute. Casasus (1858-1916) was one of the prominent legal and political men of his time and a major figure in Porfirio Díaz’s efforts to modernize Mexico. He was also a well-known poet and translator. "

LC name authority is Casasús, Joaquín D. (Joaquín Demetrio), 1858-1916. Digitized from LC's collection, www.archive.org/details/panamericanconfe00casa This is an address from 1906, and he was ambassador at the time. Text is in English and Spanish. and a 1905 biography that has the same picture as frontispiece. www.archive.org/details/biographicalsket01sol So, as quite often, the Bain photo seems to be an "official" photo taken earlier than the Bain organization of the photos might imply. He appears (from LC's catalog) to have translated Longfellow's Evangeline and Virgil's Bucolica (among other works) into Spanish.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_N._Funston Frederick N. Funston (September 11, 1865 – February 19, 1917) also known as Fred Funston, was a General in the United States Army, best known for his role in the Spanish-American War and the Philippine-American War. Henry Clay Merriam (November 13, 1837 – November 12, 1912) was a United States Army general. He received the United States military's highest decoration, the Medal of Honor, for his actions as a Union officer in command of African American troops during the American Civil War. He later served in various Indian Wars throughout the western United States and commanded the 7th Infantry Regiment. After being promoted to brigadier general, he took on a training and supply role during the Philippine–American War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Clay_Merriam

James Keteltas Hackett (1869-1926) was a Canadian-born American stage actor. The first Mrs. J. K. Hackett was Engilsh stage actress Mary Mannering (1876-1953); the couple married in 1897. They had one child, Elise. In 1908, Mary began divorce proceedings, but then called them off; in 1909, James had financial problems enough to make the papers. In time, James Hackett married English actress Beatrice Mary Beckley (b. 1885, married Hackett in 1911), and Mary Mannering married another man, Frederick E. Wadsworth. If this image was made in 1914, that should be the second Mrs. Hackett, Beatrice Mary Beckley. Beatrice and James starred together in a 1913 film of The Prisoner of Zenda. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Keteltas_Hackett www.imdb.com/name/nm0065773/ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Mannering

Henriette Caillaux (1874-1942) From Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henriette_Caillaux "Henriette Caillaux was a Parisian socialite and second wife of the former Prime Minister of France. She is remembered as an assassin. . . "Madame Caillaux believed that the only way for her husband [Joseph Caillaux, France's Minister of Finance] to defend his reputation would be to challenge [the editor of the Le Figaro newspaper Gaston] Calmette to a duel, which, one way or another, would destroy her and her husband's life. Madame Caillaux made the decision to protect her beloved husband by sacrificing herself. On 16 March 1914, the elegant and sophisticated woman walked to the newspaper's offices where she confronted the editor. After a few words, she pulled out a pistol and fired several shots point-blank into the man's chest, killing him instantly."
C'est une bizarre histoire!

Grand Duchess Olga Nikolaevna of Russia (Olga Nikolaevna Romanova) (Russian: Великая Княжна Ольга Николаевна; November 15 [O.S. November 3] 1895, November 16 after 1900 – July 17, 1918) was the eldest daughter of the last autocratic ruler of the Russian Empire, Emperor Nicholas II, and of Empress Alexandra of Russia. During her lifetime, Olga's future marriage was the subject of great speculation within Russia. Matches were rumored with Grand Duke Dmitri Pavlovich of Russia, Crown Prince Carol of Romania, Edward, Prince of Wales, eldest son of Britain's George V, and with Crown Prince Alexander of Serbia. Olga herself wanted to marry a Russian and remain in her home country. Olga's murder following the Russian Revolution of 1917 resulted in her canonization as a passion bearer by the Russian Orthodox Church. In later years, when dozens of people made claims to be surviving members of the imperial family, a woman named Marga Boodts claimed to be Grand Duchess Olga, but her claim was not taken seriously. Olga was assassinated along with her family at Ekaterinburg. Her remains were identified through DNA testing and were buried during a funeral ceremony in 1998 at Peter and Paul Cathedral in St. Petersburg along with those of her parents and two of her sisters. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Duchess_Olga_Nikolaevna_of_Ru... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Duchess_Tatiana_Nikolaevna_of...

Jerome Napoleon Charles Bonaparte (1878-1945), son of Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte II (1830 – 1893) and Caroline Le Roy Appleton Edgar (1840-1911). Married Blanche Pierce Stenbeigh (1872-1950) in 1914. The bigger news in 1914 was Jerome Bonaparte - an American - was, for a while, in line to rise to the head of France's Imperialist Party (the party seeking the restoration of the Monarchy in France). But alas, such a possibility was dashed by the birth of Louis, Prince Napoléon (1914-1997) to Victor, Prince Napoléon (1862-1926) and Princess Clémentine of Belgium (1872-1955) on January 23, 1914. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0D14F7345F13738... HEIR TO BONAPARTIST PRETENDER ENDS AMERICAN HOPES New York Times February 8, 1914 PRINCESS CLEMENTINE of Belgium, by presenting her husband, Prince Victor Bonaparte, with a son and heir the other day at Brussels, has rendered more remote, if indeed she has not removed altogether, the possibility of an American citizen becoming the candidate of the Imperialist Party in France, for a restoration of the monarchy on the banks of the Seine. NOTE: Jerome Bonaparte is also the step-brother of Commander Webster A. Edgar (USN), who was featured in the last round of Bain/LOC photos. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5285332949/]

Smith who had "previously been commissioned as Governor of Guam. www.worldstatesmen.org/Guam.html indicates he was Governor of Guam from 30 May 1916 to 15 Nov 1918 and lists him as Roy Campbell Smith. NYT of March 25, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60812FC345E13738... names Capt. Roy C. Smith as in command of the Arkansas. www.history.navy.mil/photos/albums/s582/s582-i.htm places Capt. Roy C. Smith as in command of the Arkansas in December 1913. The album has a couple of pictures of him at a distance; they are consistent with this picture (white beard), but hardly confirming. The Arkansas participated in the landings at Vera Cruz.

www.navsource.org/archives/01/33a.htm has identified this picture as of Capt. Roy Campbell Smith and says "Captain Roy Campbell Smith was the commanding officer of the battleship Arkansas (BB-33) from 17 Sept. 1912 to 13 Oct. 1914." So this picture belongs with the earlier batch of pictures of Navy Officers associated with the actions at Vera Cruz and Tampico on the Atlantic coast of Mexico.

Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree (17 December 1852 – 2 July 1917) was an English actor and theatre manager. Tree began performing in the 1870s. By 1887, he was managing the Haymarket Theatre, winning praise for adventurous programming and lavish productions, and starring in many of its productions. In 1899, he helped fund the rebuilding, and became manager, of His Majesty's Theatre. Again, he promoted a mix of Shakespeare and classic plays with new works and adaptations of popular novels, giving them spectacular productions in this large house, and often playing leading roles. His wife, actress Helen Maud Holt, often played opposite him and assisted him with management of the theatres. Although Tree was regarded as a versatile and skilled actor, particularly in character roles, by his later years, his technique was seen as mannered and old fashioned. He founded the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in 1904 and was knighted, for his contributions to theatre, in 1909. His famous family includes his siblings, explorer Julius Beerbohm, author Constance Beerbohm and caricaturist Max Beerbohm. His daughters were the actresses Viola and Felicity and poet Iris, and his illegitimate children included film director Carol Reed. A grandson was the actor Oliver Reed. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Herbert_Tree

George Schlosser (1857-?) of Sioux Falls, Dakota

GEORGE SCHLOSSER.
In newspaper circles the name of George Schlosser is widely known, for through an extended period he was connected with newspaper publication and news service. At the present time, however, he has retired from that field and is concentrating his efforts upon the management of his private business affairs and upon the furtherance of public activities and benevolent work, which make a strong appeal to him. He was born in Lodi, Wisconsin, September 3, 1857. His father, Henry Schlosser, a native of Germany, came to the United States in the early '50s. He was by trade a wagon maker and blacksmith and became identified with industrial interests at Lodi, where he conducted business until after the outbreak of the Civil war. He enlisted in the United States army during the latter part of that struggle and came to Dakota territory with General Sully, serving with the frontier forces for about fifteen months. He spent the later years of his life in Sioux Falls, passing away at the home of his son George in 1907, when he had reached the ripe old age of seventy-six years. His wife, who was Mrs. Frederica Schlosser. died during the early boyhood of their son George, who was the eldest of a family of six children.
In the public schools of Lodi. Wisconsin, George Schlosser was educated and later began learning the printer's trade in his home city. He was eager to master the business and continued in the house where he was originally employed, winning promotion from one position to another until 1883, when he came to Dakota territory. He settled first at Blunt, where he remained for five years, there establishing and conducting the Blunt Advocate. He afterward became a resident of Aberdeen, where he owned and published the Aberdeen Daily News. In 1896 he removed to Sioux Falls, where he established the ready print service, conducting business under the name of the South Dakota Newspaper Union. This undertaking, carefully managed by Mr. Schlosser, became a distinct success and advanced him far on the high road to fortune. In 1911 he disposed of the business and since that time has devoted his energies to his private business affairs and investments and to the many public undertakings in which he is deeply interested and which have constituted a vital force in pushing forward the wheels of progress in this section of the state. He served for some time as the efficient and popular secretary of the Commercial Club, his efforts in that direction being highly resultant and beneficial. He resigned in July, 1914. to take up the promotion of the Sioux Falls & Western Railway, which project is destined to make tributary to Sioux Falls an important section of the state with large natural resources needing a market outlet. He was the promoter of the Carpenter Hotel and has been largely instrumental in bringing various business enterprises and valuable commercial projects to the city. He is one of the directors and stockholders of the Queen City Fire Insurance Company and his private investments have been of an important and gratifying character.
Mr. Schlosser is free from partisan bias in his efforts for the public good and thus casts an independent local ballot, but where national issues are involved votes with the republican party. He was postmaster of the city and is president of the Sioux Falls public library and along lines which tend to ameliorate the hard conditions of life for the unfortunate he has done important and helpful work. He is president of the South Dakota Children's Home Society and has been deeply interested in this most worthy charity since its foundation

John Henry Slattery was born in New York, served in the Colorado State House of Representatives, 1911-1914, and was speaker of the State House in 1914;  he died in 1933.  When he wasn't a legislator, he was in the mining business.
I added him to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Henry_Slattery

The Logan Republican. (Logan, Utah) 1902-1924, May 07, 1914, Image 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058246/1914-05-07/ed-... indicates that Slattery had just been selected as Democratic Caucus candidate for speaker of the Colorado House, ensuring his election as speaker. Presumably the picture with the gavel is after he was made Speaker.

Presumably the trial of Charles Becker, which took place in 1912. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Becker Charles Becker (July 26, 1870 – July 30, 1915) was a New York City police officer in the 1890s-1910s and who was tried, convicted and executed for ordering the murder of a Manhattan gambler, Herman Rosenthal in the Becker-Rosenthal trial. Becker was the first American police officer to receive the death penalty for murder. The scandal that surrounded his arrest, conviction, and execution was one of the most important in Progressive Era New York in the 1890s to 1910s.

Torreon, in northern Mexico was a scene of much fighting between rebels and federals in 1913-1914 and again in the rebellion of 1929.

www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/atlas_mexico/constitutionalist_re... provides a map of Mexico with indicators of military activity by different groups during the "Constitutionalist Revolution" of 1913-1914. Torreon is shown as an area where Federal forces (in support of Huerta while he was president, February 18, 1913 – July 15, 1914) resisted the Revolutionary Army. These folks are supporting: Ejercito Federal -- which I believe means Federal Army Gobierno Constituido -- which possibly means Established/constituted Government, judging from www.fas.org/sgp/eprint/foechile.html Perhaps someone more familiar with Mexican history and terminology could confirm.

¿Que pasó en Torreón el 4 de abril de 1914 (scratched on right border 4/4//14, mirror view)?
El hecho de guerra conocido como "La  Batalla de Torreón" culminó con la entrada triunfal de los generales Maclovio Herrera, Orestes Pereyra, Eugenio Aguirre Benavides, Tomás Urbina y José Rodríguez a las 8 de la mañana; y Francisco Villa a las 9 del día 3 de abril.
Villa traía la resolución de expulsar a la colonia española, ya que los hacendados, comerciantes e industriales de esta etnia habían festejado descorchando champaña al derrocamiento y asesinato de Madero en febrero de 1913 (por lo tanto dieron su apoyo al Gobierno Usurpador [Constituido=stablished by non-constitutional means] de Huerta a quien el Ejercito Federal sostenía).  La colonia española en Torreón era numerosísima y muchos buscaron refugio en los hoteles, pero la gran mayoría lo hizo en el sótano del Banco de la Laguna (esquina de avenida Juárez y calle Cepeda, frente a la Plaza de Armas), a donde entró Villa y les dirigió un discurso a manera de regaño. Les menciona que para que no se digera que era un asesino no los fusilaría como se merecían y que les daba 48 horas para que abandonaran el país.
Pero la fecha 4 de abril deja muchas dudas.  ¿Donde estaba el ejército federal ese día?  La respuesta es en SAN PEDRO DE LAS COLONIAS.  Entonces esta multitud está concentrada en la plaza de armas de San Pedro, dando la bienvenida al Gral. José Refugio Velasco y a su Ejército Federal que apoyaban al Gobierno Constituido [NO CONSTITUCIONAL] de Victoriano Huerta.
Dr. Roberto Duarte
Cirujano Plástico

See articles "Federals Flee From Torreón" in THE OGDEN STANDARD, issue Friday, April 3, 1914,  and "San Pedro Has Been Captured" in THE ANDERSON INTELLIGENCER, issue April 10, 1914. (Both from:  The Library of Congress, Cronicling America). So that, if the picture was taken at Torreón, the date is not april 4, 1914, and if the date is correct, it was  not taken at Torreón.  IF IT WAS TAKEN AT TORREÓN the most likely date should be April 2, 1913, when Gen. Ignacio Bravo arrived to this city by orders of Gen. Huerta, so commanding a huge column of the Ejército Federal that supported the Gobierno Constituido.  Among wealthy citizens in Torreón, former supporters to Gen. Reyes, that became supporters to Huerta throurgh Manuel Garza Aldape.

Saltillo, capital of the Coahuila State, situated almost on the extreme south east of the state.
In this photo the camera is facing north-east (upper margin and right upper corner of the picture) 
To your left runs Lic. Benito Juárez Street; to your right, Emilio Castelar, both surround the cathedral, here seen by behind.  The first street back to the cathedral is General Nicolás Bravo, the second, General Victoriano Cepeda, third, José María Arteaga.  In fourht, almost in foreground, in front of lumber industry runs Mariano Matamoros Street.
On the post stamp-like (left lower corner is scratched 5/12/14 (May 12, 1914).  By then Villa was taking Paredón, Coahuila (about 35 miles west to Saltillo).   See El Paso Herald (The Library of Congress, Cronicling America), issue May 11, 1914:  "SALTILLO SIEGE IS INAUGRATED BY REBEL ARMY".  The city fell into rebels hands on May 21st, see The New York Times, issue May 23, 1914, besides the article, shows the ruins of Saltillo Casino, located in Benito Juárez and Hidalgo Streets (from this view, to the left of the cathedral).

Possibly the subject of the first paragraph of www.history.navy.mil/danfs/h3/harry_lee.htm "Harry Lee was born in Washington, D.C., 4 June 1872 and was appointed second lieutenant in the Marine Corps for the war with Spain 2 August 1898. He served at the Havana Naval Station during the war and in various ships of the Navy and Marine Corps stations following it. Joining the 6th Regiment in 1917, Lee commanded It at Chateau Thierry, St. Mihiel, and the Argonne Forest and marched with the Army to the Rhine. After the war he commanded the Marine Brigade in Santo Domingo, sent in 1921 to pacify the country and establish constitutional government. For 3 years he served as military governor of the country. Later General Lee commanded Marine Barracks, Parris Island, and while in command of the Marine base at Quantico, Va., died 1 March 1933. For World War I service Major General Lee was awarded the Army and Navy Distinguished Service Medals, the French Legion of Honor, and other decorations." Which is repeated at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Lee_%28USMC%29

An aside: www.familyorigins.com/users/s/a/l/Thomas-W-Saltmarsh-jr/F... disagrees with other sources as to when he died. It gives date of death as May 13, 1935. It agrees that he died at Quantico. Note that the two sources I cited above also disagree on his date of death.

The NYT of May 14, 1935 supports the May 13, 1935 date for his death. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20E15F83A5D167A... [subscription required] March 1, 1933 is given as the date he assumed command at Quantico.

I know it's highly unlikely, but I keep thinking this man looks like he could be my great-great-great uncle 1st Lieutenant James B. Burrows who was with the 9th Regiment New York Volunteer Cavalry from 1861 until August 25, 1864 when he was killed in battle. 
A photo of him titled "NY State Adj Gen Coll RG526s B5A F487 1st Lt James B Burrows.jpg" can be found on the United States Army Heritage and Education Center, Carlisle, PA website. 
An article honoring him for his bravery and sacrifice was printed in the New York Times on August 31, 1864 on page 8, and a scan of it is archived on the Library of Congress website. 
I believe James Burrows was promoted to 1st Lieutenant in 1862. 
Does anyone recognize the location where this photo might have been taken? There is not much to go by other than the fence, roof of a building  behind it, and a couple of tall tree trunks, and the forest in the background. I have been collecting information about James B. Burrows and am hoping to learn a little more about this mystery soldier and his very beautiful but thin horse who appears to be a thoroughbred stallion. Another small clue might be the horse's markings, and particularly the unusual white patch in the horse's mane, perhaps from a healed battle scar? Horses can get white patches from healed injuries such as saddle sores, freeze brands, etc.

Since the man in this photo was a soldier of the Confederate Army, then did he go on to join the Union (US) Army after the Civil War had ended, if he had managed to survive the battles and remained fit for combat? Because shortly after the Civil War had ended, the US Government had resumed the wars against those Native Americans who belonged to the various nomadic tribes.

After surrender, the Confederate soldiers were to cease hostilities and return home. Some enlisted soldiers may have joined the Army afterward, and a number of Confederate officers did re-join the US Army after the war but most went back to civilian lives. Most Union soldiers also returned to civilian life after the war.

Smith was enrolled in the 52nd Virginia Infantry 15 July 1861 at age 18, and was 4th Sergeant, Company B. He served with them until February 1862, when he furnished a substitute and was discharged (3 March). It is likely, then, that the photo here was taken between July 1861 and March 1862.

He enlisted as Private in the 1st Cavalry in either the spring of 1863 or early 1864.  He was wounded in action at Kennon’s Landing (24 May 64), then in hospital in Richmond and on furlough into September. He returned to his unit and was paroled at Staunton, Virginia in May 1865. For most of his life he was a farmer and merchant near Waynesboro, where he is buried at Riverview Cemetery.

Roster sources: Robert Driver's histories in the H. Howard Virginia Regimental Series for the 52nd Va Infantry and 1st Va Cavalry.

This COULD very well be a photo of my 1st cousin 4x removed. He served in Co. D in the 9th Maryland (Union) Infantry. On 18 October 1863 he found himself in Charleston, West Virginia, when the town was surrounded and attacked by Confederate General John Daniel Imboden, 62nd Virginia Mounted Infantry. He was captured and held prisoner at Andersonville.

It was during this time, June, 1863 - November, 1864 (17 months), his wife evidently became pregnant, but he could not possibly be the father. She sought out one, Doctor S.D. Kell, seeking to obtain an abortion 'during an advanced stage'. Dr. Kell gave her a lethal dose of a poison designed to cause an abortion and evidently lied to authorities to cover his mistake. Dr. Kell was charged with murder. He posted a $5,000.00 bond and was released pending trial.

In December, 1864, my ancestor was paroled. He returned to Baltimore, Maryland, and was mustered out of the Army. But his Civil War service wasn't over. In March, 1865 he enlisted in the 91st Pennsylvania Infantry, Company C. This unit was present at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, April, 1865, when General Robert E. Lee surrendered to General Ulysses Grant. He was mustered out of the Army in July 1865.

I know who this is but it is kind of a long story. A few years back I bought 3 ambrotypes from an estate picker in Florida. I never knew where they found the images, but there were three pictures in a lot which included a ninth plate of a Confederate Ordnance Sergeant, a Confederate Captain, and a South Carolina Militia Officer. All three pics came right out of the woodwork, and were not images compiled in a group, but rather a set that were found together after sitting in an estate for 100+ years. The Sgt. had an ID in period ink on the cushion of the photograph that said "Father of R I Barnes."...when I got the photographs, I noticed that the backside of the picture said "William Sharpe Barnes, 19 years old"...I researched the name but didn't find anything solid. Just last week, I did a general search of William Sharpe Barnes on Google, and there was a hit on www.findagrave.com. I saw that the soldier was born in 1843, so this was a possibility. I looked at the site and saw that the Sgt. rose in rank to Lt., and then to Aide-de-Camp for General Bryan Grimes of the 4th North Carolina...WOW!!!....On the find a grave site, the information stated that William had 4 children. The last child on the list was Ralph Ivor Barnes (R I Barnes)...YES!!!!...There was the hit I was looking for...It solidified the ID of the soldier to the bone. The other thing I noticed on the site was that William had a brother, Jesse Sharpe Barnes, who graduated from the Univ. of North Carolina and enlisted as a Captain in the 4th N.C. Infantry. There is my other ninth plate ambrotype. An ambro of a Captain, and it is the same guy as the soldier on Flickr above. There is no doubt in my mind that my ambrotype of the Captain is William's brother. He enlisted as a Captain and was killed at Seven Pines, Virginia in 1862. I am attaching a link to the find a grave site to show what I found. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=462670... I believe with 99% confidence that the soldier on flickr is Jesse Sharpe Barnes of the 4th N.C. Infantry. Other than the mustache and hat, it is the same guy...no doubt about it. Please see my two ambrotypes at i34.photobucket.com/albums/d131/BryanWatson/tom64.jpg .... and ... i34.photobucket.com/albums/d131/BryanWatson/tom40.jpg ....This is my conclusion to why the above flickr image is Jesse Sharpe Barnes, Captain of the 4th N.C. KIA at Seven Pines, Virginia in 1862.....No doubt at all!!!

Thanks so much for recovering Jesse Sharpe Barnes' identify and for writing out the fascinating story of all 3 ambrotypes and how the names fell together! Here's the full bio from Find A Grave: "William's older brother, Jesse Sharpe Barnes (1838-1862) also enlisted with the NC 4th and served as a Captain. He was killed May 31, 1862 at the Battle of Seven Pines." Since William S. Barnes had two older brothers, I did check for a second confirming source. And, the entries in the Civil War Soldiers-Sailors system, www.itd.nps.gov/cwss/soldiers.cfm, support your conclusion. Of the 11 men with the surname "Barnes" in the 4th Regiment, North Carolina Infantry, only one is a captain -- Jesse S., of Co. F. The entry for William S. Barnes lists a corporal (rank in) / adjutant (rank out), also of Co. F. We'll update the catalog record with credit to your research! -- Helena

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress]

This "Confederate" uniform looks as much as many of the Union frock coats pictured prior to this one. At the outbreak of hostilities, BOTH sides wore Blue and Grey interchangeably. That is definetely a member of the 2nd corps of the Army of the Potomac. The corps was first organised March 13, 1862 and dismantled June 28, 1865. So the photo is from between those two dates.

Corps badges were developed by Hooker shortly after he took command of the Army of the Potomac in early '63.
Gauging from the shade of grey that this 2nd Corps badge is, I'd say it's safe to say that it is a 2nd Corps, 2nd Division badge, which would have been white.  The 1st and 3rd division colors, for all Corps badges, were red and blue, respectively, and would be seen as much darker in these old black and white photos.  
The 2nd Division of the 2nd Corps is noteworthy for being at the stone wall during Pickett's Charge.

It wasnt Hooker who developed/designed the actual badges. He might have instituted them officially though.

This is what is said bout corps badges on General Philip Kearnys wiki-site.

Kearny is credited with devising the first unit insignia patches used in the U.S. Army. In the summer of 1862, he issued an order that his officers should wear a patch of red cloth on the front of their caps to identify themselves as members of his unit. The enlisted men, with whom Kearny was quite popular, quickly followed suit of their own volition. Members of other units picked up on the idea, devising their own insignia, and these evolved over the years into the modern shoulder patch. (Daniel Butterfield is credited with taking Kearny's idea and standardizing it for all corps in the Army of the Potomac, designing most of the corps badges.) Kearny was promoted to major general on July 4, 1862.

wow1919: Thanks for carefully looking at these images. This photograph is a tintype. Most tintype images appear reversed because the photographer made a positive image on a sheet of iron (no negative was involved). However, some cameras had mirrors or a 45 degree prism which would correct the image. Photographers could also re-photograph the image to get a "correct" view. You can take a look at this article on tintypes: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tintype

Anyone know what those letters mean?

“VMM" stands for "Volunteer Militia of Maine".

"Modeled after the regulation 1839 pattern infantry plates, these small waist belt plates were accompanied by large VMM cartridge box plates.  Because the prewar military establishment of Maine fielded no cavalry of reflemen, large waist belt plates and small cartridge box plates were not necessary.  These plates were purchased at some point between the adoption of a state button in 1855 and the outbreak of war in 1861.  The Army had switched to large waist belt plates by 1857 but a number of states adhered to the old pattern through 1862.  A considerable quantity of this style was acquired as many have been recovered from the battlefields and camps of Virginia."*

"The Volunteer Militia of Maine (VMM), as it was formally named, was organized in 1851 and restructured in 1861 to raise and equip ten regiments of volunteer infantry for two years of Federal service.  It appears that most of these men were initially outfitted by the state with VMM plates in accordance with the Army's 1839 regulations."*

*Michael J. O'Donnell & J. Duncan Campbell, American Military Belt Plates (Alexandria, Virginia: O' Donnell Publications, 1996), 342-3.

No. Again, I believe this is a Confederate. If CSA or state buckles were scarce they would reverse acquired Union ones,  a common practice.

Addendum: The high collar was much more common in Southern enlisted men's uniforms. Also, the rather ancient looking smoothbore musket. Even early on, Union soldiers had better rifles, by and large, though recently cartridge boxes found at Antietam (Sharpsburg) showed some Union Infantry units were still carrying smoothbores in late 1862
That sounds reasonable.  I also note now that the "U" was painted in upside down, so whatever the reason it wasn't accidental.

Upside down US buckle is a clue this fellow may have been a regular US infantryman until his state seceded. Or it is a captured or liberated belt. The jaunty brim angle of his kepi say "Johnny Reb" to me. Men fighting on the southern side were predominantly volunteers and tended to express such positive fighting spirit throughout the war.

He is most likely a federal soldier. It's not an upside down belt buckle, it's an upside down belt. The whole thing is upside down because he flipped it to wear on the opposite side of his body. The cap box is also upside down. He knew that the photo would inverse everything and they sometimes compensated for that. Doing it like this made the bayonet scabbard on the (to the viewer) "correct" side of the body.

Now that seems to make the most sense -- I didn't notice the cap box.  I note he's holding his rifle with a left-handed grip, probably for the same reason, and there are a dozen or so pictures in this collection with the upside-down belt like this one.  

Only now I wonder why, if the photographer was going to retouch the buckle anyway, he didn't paint it correctly.
The image is a mirror image, and the buckle is upside down for a reason; he is a Confederate soldier. The captured buckles from Federal depots were turned upside down and used as needed.
Also, the upside-down buckle resembled a "N.S." which stood for "New South"

Intriguing picture... the man doesn't look like he's holding the gun to the other fellow's head to me, though.  He seems to be holding the revolver across his chest, not an uncommon pose at the time.  If he were actually joking and holding it at the man seated, it seems it would be a little lower and tilted.  And... what might the gentleman standing on the right be looking at?  The other four all appear to be looking straight into the camera... except for the other man standing.  Some noise or a movement caught his attention at just that moment?  Perhaps mom or sweetheart talking to him?  Fanciful thoughts...

Agreed. It's a pose, not a joke. It's pointed at his own arm, and he's behind the seated man far enough to accommodate the chair he's sitting in and the crook of his arm as he's resting it on the man's shoulder.
What about the two holding hands? Seems rather strange, unless they were related.

Were these guys serious or not?  They aren't "clowning around." If it was meant to be humorous, it was a very dry humor, and one of them wasn't on board with that at all (to the far left). And would they waste a studio photograph by being silly? Maybe. Had they been drinking? Did the photographer suggest some silly posing? The hand-holding man seated is also holding his head in a way that enhances the feeling of intimacy between them. The man standing is definitely not.

I've seen other photographs of Civil War soldiers who were engaged in displays of affection, some more overt than this.  This is one of those instances where we need to be careful not to revise history based on our own frames of reference, but - joking or not, I think these poses implied then what they would imply  today. There was certainly physical and/or emotional intimacy (sexual/romantic) among male soldiers at that time, but it seems highly unlikely they would immortalize this in a photo that would, presumably, be seen by friends and family. I don't think male relatives that had a close relationship would pose like this.  It would be really interesting to be able to go back and ask them! 

The standing man not looking at the camera - that isn't a daydreaming gaze, in my opinion, it's a blank stare. The photographer would have told them not to move. I've seen a lot of early photos where people have a stiff look like this. And - he's holding another man's hand. Joking or not, he's probably not daydreaming about his mom or sweetheart.

Wild guess:  One non-romantic reason that the men might be holding hands (or touching hands) so freely and visibly would be if the man in back were blind.  He might well have a hand on his friend's shoulder, just as it appears here, and the friend might simply be touching or holding his hand as a signal or reassurance.  That might also account for his gaze being off from the direction his friends are looking.

I believe the men "holding hands" were doing so due to a strong sense of camaraderie - or, at least - to create that impression. Camaraderie between troops (on both sides) was very strong, and, back then, they were not opposed to the physical expression of such. Homosexuality was taboo, particularly amongst the military, so any "romantic" expression is extremely unlikely, especially since they are being photographed with compatriots. "Holding hands", in any public arena, would have more than likely resulted in the participants being, at a minimum,  tarred and feathered.

I'm guessing that they are related or compatriots. Back then, displays of affection were not seen in the same way as they are today. Also, I agree that the gun holder is simply displying the gun by holding it across his chest for the photograph.
he's not clowning with that gun -- he's showing it off. it's obviously his pride!

In certain parts of the world, men walk around holding hands and holding hands with women, even your wife/girlfriend is taboo. I know how people love to read modern thoughts into such things.

Perhaps, just perhaps, this was one of those post-mortem posed photos which were not uncommon in the 1800's and wherein the eyes were often painted black dots on closed eyelids.  The two in the back could be keeping his head propped up with their elbows, and the fabric pulling on the potentially deceased shoulder could be because of the propping arm.  The hand he has partially raised could be held up by the right-back man, as the seated (potentially deseased) man seems to have no real grasp look to his hand.  The man seated to the right is sitting up straight with shoulders back, but the middle fellow isn't sitting up with intentional pose, although the guy on the left is also slouching, he could also be deceased with his head also being propped by the other elbow.  Just a possibility, as this photo is odd by today's standards in a few ways.   And I agree that the guy is holding his gun up, but not at the seated man's head.

NYT of May 3, 1914, reports on the cardinal leaving Baltimore for New York, whence he would sail for Europe to visit the Pope. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9803EFD81E39E633A... It reports that he would sail on the Prinzess[in] Irene with the Rev. Louis R. Stickney.

The Baltimore Archbishop got there okay: the New York Times of May 27, 1914, reports that Cardinal Gibbons, in Rome, on May 26 hosted a dinner for sixty; his guests included ten cardinals: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9902E3DC1F39E6... While in Rome, Gibbons paid a farewill visit to the dying Pope Pius X (who described himself as a permanent exile from his beloved Venice). In July 1914, after Pius died, Gibbons had to make a return visit to Rome for the Conclave that elected the next Pope, Benedict XV.

En Wikipedia encontré:
General Juan Gualberto Amaya fue un militar mexicano que participó en la Revolución mexicana. Originario de Santa María del Oro, Durango. Desde 1913 se afilió a las fuerzas que se levantaron en aquellos contornos contra Victoriano Huerta, pero sus operaciones militares importantes las realizó bajo las órdenes del General Francisco Murguía en la campaña contra Francisco Villa en el norte del país, entre 1917 y 1919. Se unió al pronunciamiento del Plan de Agua Prieta contra el Presidente Venustiano Carranza; después fue leal al gobierno del General Álvaro Obregón, alcanzando el grado de General Brigadier. Triunfó en la lucha electoral para ser Gobernador de Durango en el periodo de 1928 a 1932, tomando posesión del cargo el 15 de septiembre de 1928; sin embargo, en marzo del año siguiente se adhirió al Plan de Hermosillo, obrando de acuerdo con el Jefe de las Operaciones en el estado, el General Francisco Urbalejo, para secundar al General José Gonzalo Escobar, que se había pronunciado en Torreón. Abandonó el gobierno al fracasar este movimiento además de que el gobierno federal le desconoció su grado militar, refugiándose en los Estados Unidos, donde permaneció varios años. Regresó después y se retiró a la vida privada. Murió en 1964.

baseballhall.org/hof/evers-johnny Biography: Johnny Evers was a smart, scrappy and determined second baseman and the pivot man in the famed Tinker-to-Evers-to-Chance infield. His knowledge of the rules enabled him to turn the 1908 National League pennant race around, as a result of the infamous Fred Merkle play. He helped lead the Chicago Cubs to four National League pennants and two world championships. After joining Boston in 1914, Evers sparked another turnaround when the Miracle Braves rose from the cellar in July to a world championship in October.

The caption on the original photo denotes SS St. Paul, and her sister ship SS St. Louis in parentheses (presumably to use the same stock photo when illustrating either ship). After looking at the larger version of this photo, and squinting a bit, it appears that this is actually a photo of the SS St. Louis.

this photo is used in Wiki as St Louis en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_St._Louis_(1894) SS St. Louis, a transatlantic passenger liner built by the William Cramp & Sons Building & Engine Company, Philadelphia, Pa., was launched on 12 November 1894; sponsored by Mrs. Grover Cleveland, wife of the President of the United States; and entered merchant service in 1895, under United States registry for the International Navigation Co., of New York with her maiden voyage between New York and Southampton, England. She was acquired by the United States Navy during the Spanish–American War and commissioned under the name USS St. Louis in 1898, and again during World War I under the name USS Louisville (ID-1644) from 1918 to 1919.[Note 1] After she reverted to her original name in 1919, she burned in 1920 while undergoing a refit. St. Louis was scrapped in 1924 in Genoa. Wiki has a photo of St Paul but no apparent article en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:SS_St._Paul.jpg
In Spring/Summer 1914, both St. Louis and St. Paul served as passenger liners on transatlantic routes to England.  According to Shipping News in NYT.
rescued the crew of the SS Chester after it was disabled in a gale in 1915 www.aukevisser.nl/esso/id23.htm her sister was SS New York
Check out the clipper bow, complete with figurehead!

here is her sister SS New York in Liverpool. They were the first twin screw steamers, with long interesting histories. Her she is in her original fittings with 3 funnels in service with the Inman line. Launched in 1888 (City of NY) and 1889 (City of Paris),they each quickly won the Blue Ribband. Both were used by the US Navy as auxiliary cruisers in the Spanish-American War (as Harvard and Yale) Returned to service and renamed New York and Philadelphia for the American Line. In 1901-3 New York was refitted with 2 funnels and new triple expansion engines. Philadelphia (Yale) was stranded during the war and salvaged. She got her 2 funnels and was returned to service in 1901 as Philadelphia with the American Line. Both became troop transports and were renamed again in 1918 (as Plattsburg and Harrisburg) and both were broken up in 1923 in Genoa

In April 1914, the New York did a passenger run from Southampton to New York, arriving April 19th. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E7D81E39E633A... And in June 1914, the Philadelphia did a run in the other direction. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E02E7DE143EE733A...

Does anyone know what the SS Macona was doing in Britian (Wallsend)  in 1917?
My Great Grandfather's marriage certificate lists him as a US Navy Gunner and his address as the SS Macon, Swan and Hunter Dry Dock, Wallsend.  He married an English woman and he was American born in Philadelphia.

In 1916 the ship was sold to the Barber Steamship Co., renamed Macona, and possibly reconfigured as a freighter by her new owner. Taken over by the Navy and commissioned at New York as USS Macona (ID # 3305) on 19 August 1918, she sailed in a convoy on 25 August with a cargo of 4,470 tons of general supplies, which she delivered to St. Nazaire, France, on 12 September. She was then assigned to service in European waters, carrying a cargo of potatoes from Ireland to France for the American Expeditionary Force. In late December Macona loaded a cargo of Navy stores, then moved to Cardiff, Wales, to bunker for the voyage back to the United States. She left Cardiff on 15 February 1919 www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-m/id3305.htm

Thanks nudecowboy. I found the info about being commisioned at New York on the Naval Website. However, I have a document of my Greatgrandfathers in my possession listing the SS Macona as his address while he was stationed in England in August 1917 during WWI.

I can't quite tell what plane this is (looks like an early wing-warper), but most early war planes were used for observation work (troop movements &  ground photography) and were not "Fighter planes".  I suspect this was more of an observation plane then a "Fighter Plane" mostly since the extra weight of gunner, wing warping (IE- no wing rudders, the wings would be pulled by pulleys and warp) and the increased wind shield would have made this plane pretty slow and not very maneuverable.

For early biplanes they would have mounted the gun/guns on the upper wing above the prop, or in some cases, they would armour the prop and just threw it.
