The above photo probably was taken in the summer of 1913, when Howie Camnitz was still pitching for the Pittsburgh Pirates. His start that year was lackluster, so he was banished to the Philadelphia team, where he didn't do much better. Early in 1914, he grabbed a chance to return to Pittsburgh by joining a new team, the Pittsburgh Rebels -- one of eight teams in the newly-formed Federal League (whose existence was brief). The report of his leap to the Federals likely was the news event that impelled the Bain News Agency to circulate this photo of Camnitz to its subscribers. Camnitz continued with the Rebels in 1915, but retired from baseball in that year, because of problems with his pitching arm.

The photo shows DePalma at the time of winning of the 200-mile 1914 Vanderbilt Cup race, which followed an eight-mile course over the public roads of Santa Monica, California. The date was February 26, 1914. The race took nearly four hours, and De Palma won $3,000. Story in The New York Times, February 27, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A04E5DE163AE6...

A bizarre footnote: Hollywood moviemaker Mack Sennett (of Keystone Comedies fame) crashed the party and himself literally got into the act, making a film with Mabel Normand and Charlie Chaplin, using the Vanderbilt Race as a backdrop. Here's a clip: www.vanderbiltcupraces.com/index.php/blog/article/1914_va...

"Dago Frank" Cirofici (Cirocici, Carofici, Cirosici) was a petty criminal in New York City convicted of murdering Herman Rosenthal with his fellow assasins Harry Horowitz "Gyp the Blood", Louis Rosenberg (Rosenweig) "Lefty Louis", and "Whitey" Lewis (Frank Seidenshner) at 1 o'clock in the morning on July 16, 1912. Herman Rosenthal had threatened to "squeal" on Lieutenant Charles Becker (NYC Police) concerning his involvement in gambling if Becker didn't remove his "strong arm squad" of police after a raid was made in early April. Herman was in the process of telling his story when Becker hired the four men and developed the plot that led to Herman's execution in front of the Hotel Metropolis on 43rd Street. The four men were executed at Sing Sing in April 13, 1914 with "Dago Frank" being the first to die. Before his death he stated that he was five miles away when the murder as committed. All four men were taken to funeral homes on the East Side after their deaths.

Information taken from articles in the Syracuse Herald from 1912-1914.

There was a school for deaconesses associated with the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. August 17, 1913, NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E03E1DB113BE633A... indicates that a home for the deaconesses in training had been recently completed and that a new Synod Hall would be essentially complete by September 1, for a convention of the Episcopal Church in October. The article has a picture that looks like the building at the right (as the Synod Hall). Perhaps they didn't get the landscaping addressed fully until the next spring. Looking at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cathedral_Saint_John_Divine_NY..., I would judge that the Synod Hall is in the lower right corner of the Cathedral campus, and that the deaconesses were walking towards the cathedral when this picture was taken.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw, active for many years in the suffrage movement in New York. Her letter to the editor of NYT (May 26, 1912) query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30914F63B5E13738... is signed Harriet Burton Laidlaw. Her papers are at Harvard/Radcliffe: oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00682 "Harriet Burton Laidlaw, suffragist, social and civic reformer, and internationalist, was born on December 16, 1873, in Albany, N.Y., the daughter of Alice Davenport (Wright) and George Davidson Burton. HBL attended public school in Albany, and earned both Bachelor (1895) and Master (1896) of Pedagogy degrees from Albany Normal College. After graduation she moved to New York City, taught in the public schools, and in 1902 earned degrees from Barnard College (A.B.) and Illinois Wesleyan University (Ph.B.). During this time she also took summer courses at Harvard (1900), the University of Chicago (1901), and Oxford University (1903). She continued to teach and started graduate school at Columbia University, but stopped both when she married James Lees Laidlaw in 1905. A concern with women's rights now blossomed into a remarkably active involvement in a variety of causes and organizations."

A New York Times story (May 3, 1914) about a woman suffrage rally in Union Square refers to the speakers' platform as "the porch of the cottage" --- query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F50D1EF9355D13...

Dr. Roberto Duarte: Thank you for the additional information on Martiniano Servin and the possible location of this photo. We will add some of it to the image description when we update. A similar version of this photograph is found here: repository.tamu.edu/handle/1969.1/734

En Wikipedia encontré: General Martiniano Servín fue un militar mexicano que participó en la Revolución mexicana. En 1912 tomó las armas ante la sublevación de Pascual Orozco. Formaba parte de las fuerzas irregulares comandadas por Francisco Villa, con el puesto de artillero. Combatió a Emilio P. Campa en Parral, Chihuahua. En 1913, como consecuencia de la usurpación de Victoriano Huerta, retornó a las armas y a la artillería de la División del Norte. Participó en 1913 en los ataques de Torreón, Chihuahua, Tierra Blanca y Ojinaga, bajo las órdenes directas Pánfilo Natera García. En 1914 destacó su actuación militar en las acciones de Torreón, San Pedro de las Colonias y Paredón. Apoyó a Francisco Villa en su decisión de atacar Zacatecas y sobresalió en el bombardeo de cerro de Loreto. Participó en la Convención de Aguascalientes. Ante la escisión revolucionaria continuó en las filas villistas, quedando bajo las órdenes de Felipe Ángeles y operando con el grado de coronel, más tarde lograría el grado de general brigadier. Murió en combate, el 5 de enero de 1915, en una batalla cerca de Ciudad Ramos Arizpe bajo las órdenes del general Felipe Ángeles en contra de las fuerzas de Venustiano Carranza comandadas por el famoso general Maclovio Herrera, las cuales perdieron la batalla de ese día. Venció Servín, pero perdió la vida debido a su indomable arrojo y valentía es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martiniano_Serví Dr. Roberto Duarte Cirujano Plástico

The propeller says "Garuda," which was a manufacturer in Berlin: www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200252... Outsourcing, I guess.
Igor Sikorsky (1889-1972) came to America in 1919, and became a U. S. citizen in 1928. Wikipedia on Igor Sikorsky: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky

This HAS to be a joke! The photographer is playing with perspective. If the distance between each pair of men is about 6 feet, the propeller would be around 36 feet long.  Sikorsky's giant Ilya Muromets bombers had large propellers, but they appear to be about 10 feet in diameter in most archival photos.  

There's definitely something funny going on here. Look closely at how the giant propeller is sitting on the sawhorses.

Agree with techno -- notice the four guys on the far end are standing on an inclined plane, which is monkeying with the perspective. Also the propeller itself has a weird outline, as if cut and pasted onto the photograph. On the other hand, the Germans built a plane with a 23-ft Garuda propeller ( www.markslists.net/history/germangiants/index.html ) . If the guy on the near end is about 6-ft tall, this propeller might go 23 ft.

Thanks for the link, rjones0856! 

Another possiblity is that this gigantic propeller is real but it was fabricated entirely for display, i.e. to show what the company was capable of building. It may have been shown at an air meet or a trade fair. Or maybe it was presented to Sikorsky as a gift for bringing so much business to Garuda.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Memphis_(CA-10)

If this is indeed USS Memphis (it is certainly an Omaha-class Light Cruiser), it would be CL-13, and the photo would date no earlier than the mid-1920s, not 1910 (or thereabouts). USS Memphis (CL-13) was launched at the William Cramp & Sons shipyard in Philadelphia in April 1924, and commissioned at the Philadelphia Navy Yard in February 1925. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Memphis_(CL-13)

I have to respectfully disagree. The USS Memphis (ex-Tennessee) (ACR-10/CA-10) was a very different ship than the one photographed above. USS Memphis (ex-Tennessee) (ACR-10/CA-10) featured a tumblehome/ram bow and casement gun positions along her hull, and, while approximately 50' shorter in length than an Omaha-class cruiser, was almost 20' greater in beam and twice the displacement . Also, an identifying feature of the Omaha-class cruisers (such as USS Memphis (CL-13)) was the relatively unique placement of casement guns in the superstructure (four each fore and aft), as depicted above. Of course, radical changes to a ship's appearance may come about after various refits and upgrades, but that was not the case with USS Memphis (ex-Tennessee) (ACR-10/CA-10). Here's a link to a photo of USS Memphis (CA-10) as she meets her demise in Santo Domingo harbor: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:USS_Tennessee_ACR-10_-_photo_N... I would still maintain that the ship photographed above is the later USS Memphis (CL-13), and if not, one of her Omaha-class sister-ships.

Yes, the photos definitely show two different ships. And I confess that I know virtually nothing about Navy ships -- or any ships, really. So the explanation we are left with is that the Bain negative of the Memphis has been filed more than ten years out of order -- something that happens infrequently, but does happen, perforce.

Wystan: The filing is all Bain's doing!  The Library obediently follows the photo agency's original order, indicated by the identification number scratched into the glass plate -- in this case 3019-3.  Significant date anomalies have appeared before, though.  It's speculation still, but we're wondering if the Bain agency sometimes replaced an old view of a subject with a newer view and kept the same number. Their card index already cited the ship "Memphis" as "3019-3," and when a new boat became the "Memphis" they kept the same index number and replaced the old negative with a new photo to avoid publishing a picture of the wrong boat.  I'll try to track down the other example and send it along.

Info about Abraham Gonzalez and Francisco Villa, from Wikipedia:

"Villa's hatred of ['usurper' Mexican Presidente] Huerta became more personal and intense after March 7, 1913, when Huerta ordered the murder of Villa's political mentor, Abraham González, who had worked with Madero and Villa since 1910. González had been one of Madero's political advisors. He recruited Francisco Villa in 1910 to support Madero with the Plan de San Luis which started the first part of the Mexican Revolution with the armed movement of 20 November 1910. The Plan de San Luis was conceived to force Dictator Porfirio Diaz (Mexican president for 33 years) to leave the presidency and allow for a Mexican democracy.[3] Villa later recovered González's remains and gave his friend a proper funeral in Chihuahua."

Wystan:  Thank you for pulling together these Mexican Revolution photos.   About your comment on why we don't correct  the exposure of this image--at least three concerns hold us back from editing images. 

Authenticity: Digitizing a photograph as it has survived through time reassures viewers that we're representing the original artifact faithfully. Editing an image undermines the reliability of the photo as a historical document. Once we start changing the tonal contrast of the image, who's to know how much other image content we changed.
 
Subjective choices: Different users have different preferences when it comes to pumping up contrast, sharpening edges, cropping negative borders, etc.  Offering the basic image allows users make their own decisions about which features to change to suit a particular purpose or product.

Lack of money and time: If we had more resources, offering a 'cleaned up photo' in addition to the 'raw document' could be considered.  (Like pre-conservation and post-conservation images of a damaged and then repaired poster.) But our priority is basic digital access -- many more of the Library’s 14 million pictures should be available online first.

Victuallers2 and Wystan:  Abraham Gonzalez seems to be known primarily as the Governor of the Mexican state of Chihuahua and a leader of the Mexican Revolution. However, some contemporary sources, such as an article in the St. Louis Dispatch of May 17, 1914 identify him as a general.  Possibly it was an honorific title.  Does any one else have information about this question?  In any case, we would leave "Gen." in the title, as it reflects the information provided by Bain on the negative.  We can add additional information about him to the image description.
There's a similar version of this picture in Wheelan collection of the Mexican Revolution.   In fact is a photo series of Abraham Gonzalez honored funeral ordered by Francisco Villa.

After Ciudad Juarez was taken, Villa headed on Dec. 3r 1913 to Chihuahua City, in which arrived five days later.  On Dec. 8th Villa took office as governor.  Two outstanding events occurred in that month, the expulsion of Spaniards and exhumation and honored burial (pending the day) of Don Abram González  whose corpse was accompanied by a crowd leaded by Villa, to a mausoleum in Chihuahua's cementery. So this picture (and phto LC-B2-3018-11) may be "corraled" between Dec 1913 and Feb 1914
Dr. Roberto Duarte
Plastic Reconstructive Surgeon

On February 22nd,1913, Don Abraham González was arrested by Gen. Antonio Rábago (Chief of military forces in Chihuahua State), who accepted Huerta´s Presidency.
On March 6th, 1913 a group of military men came from México City and took Don Abraham on a train and in Estación Horcasitas he was slain, shooting on his back, then they put the body on the rail so the locomotive crushed it.
On december 1913 Francisco Villa became Governor of Chihuahua, he ordered González exhumation and offered a funeral with honors in Chihuahua.
In the photo Pancho Villa is walking just behind the funeral car.
Roberto Duarte M D
You can find other pictures of Abraham González funeral in Texas A&M University Libraries clicking in hdl.handle.net/1969.1/816 and hdl.handle.net/1969.1/822 etc. Dr. Roberto Duarte Plastic Surgeon
Some pictures of Abraham González are dated February 26, 1914.

The painting is probably by George Wettling (the portrait subject) himself. The Wikipedia article on him en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Wettling says: 'Towards the end of his life, Wettling (like his friend the clarinetist Pee Wee Russell), took up painting, and was much influenced by the American cubist Stuart Davis. He has been quoted as remarking that "jazz drumming and abstract painting seemed different from him only from the point of view of craftsmanship: in both fields he felt rhythm to be decisive".' An(other) example of his painting (and similar signature) is at: www.artnet.com/Artists/LotDetailPage.aspx?lot_id=3741B700...

El 3 de enero de 1914 Villa firma en exclusiva un contrato con la Mutual Film Corporation para que filmen sus batallas y recibe como anticipos USD $25,000.00.
El 10 de enero del mismo año toma la fronteriza Ojinaga, Chihuahua (frontera con Presidio, Texas).
Esta foto y la otra en esta serie de la colección corresponden al desfile triunfal después de esa batalla que también fue filmado en "motion picture".
Acompañan a Villa a su derecha el General Toribio Ortega y a su izquierda el General Raúl Madero.
La columna de caballería viene de norte a sur, entonces la proyección de las sombras es de oriente a poniete.  Por esta proyección podemos inferir que son 8 a 9 de la mañana.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH MUTUAL FILM CO.:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thanks Wystan, for finding the information and linking the other Mutual Film images. In addition to the Bain images, the library has another great photo in our New York World- Telegraph & Sun Newspaper collection, www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2005695716/ showing Pancho Villa with members of the film crew. We'll fill in the caption information in the records for these images the next time we update them.

This is also closely linked with photo call nr LC-B2-3006-1, in which Villa is seen riding at the head of his troops, after Ojinaga was taken in Jan. 1914.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

Alexander Berkman (November 21, 1870 – June 28, 1936) was an anarchist known for his political activism and writing. He was a leading member of the anarchist movement in the early 20th century. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Berkman

This was during the mine strike in Colorado that led to the infamous Ludlow Massacre a few days later -- Berkman and the Wobblies had been leading solidarity demonstrations in New York in support of the miners, and this was likely one of those, I would guess.
Also, less than a week before this, Wobblies were clubbed and arrested by the New York police for demonstrations in Union Square: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F10C12FA3D5E13...
NYT of April 12, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9501E6DA133DE333A... describes the 4/11/1914 demonstration.

Bread and Roses was the IWW song of the times? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bread_and_Roses and from an Irish-American perspective irishhistorypodcast.ie/podcast-irish-american-radicals-th... This podcast tells the story of Irish-Americans who have been almost forgotten by history. These were the revolutionaries, feminists, socialists, and trade union organisers (including the IWW) in early 20th century United States. Often dubbed as ‘Un-American’ they strenuously rejected this notion. They saw themselves as much Americans or Irish American as much as anyone else, they just held a very different view of what America should be. Hear their fascinating story in the show. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Workers_of_the_World#Not...

She was launched on 23 March 1914, sponsored by Lorena J. Cruce, the daughter of Governor of Oklahoma Lee Cruce. USS Oklahoma (BB-37), the only ship of the United States Navy to ever be named for the 46th state, was a World War I-era battleship and the second of two ships in her class; her sister ship was Nevada. She, along with Nevada, were the first two U.S. warships to use oil fuel instead of coal. Commissioned in 1916, Oklahoma served in World War I as a member of BatDiv 6, protecting Allied convoys on their way across the Atlantic. After years of spending time in the Pacific and the Scouting Fleets, Oklahoma was modernized from 1927 to 1929. She rescued American citizens and refugees from the Spanish Civil War in 1936; after returning to the West coast in August of that year, she spent the rest of her life in the Pacific. She was sunk by Japanese bombs and torpedoes on 7 December 1941, in the attack on Pearl Harbor, taking 429 of her crew with her as she capsized. She was uprighted in 1943, but unlike most of the other battleships damaged in the Pearl Harbor attack, she was never repaired and returned to duty. Instead, Oklahoma was stripped of guns and superstructure, and sold for scrap. She sank while under tow to the mainland in 1947. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Oklahoma_(BB-37)

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH MUTUAL FILM CO.:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

TEN POLICEWOMEN CHOSEN BY MAYOR; ON DUTY MONDAY Chicago Tribune; Aug 2, 1913 Chicago will have policewomen on duty on Monday. Mayor Harrison announced the appointment of ... Some things go on In amusement parks which should not be. ... Eight of the Mayor's Appointees Don Uniforms and Get Flowers with Their Stars. New York Times; August 6, 1913 Eight of Chicago's newly appointed policewomen took the oath of office to-day with upraised hands in the office of the Secretary of Police, and after having the regulation police stars pinned upon the lapels of their tailormade jackets, they dispersed to the stations to which they were assigned. Two of the women appointed by Mayor Harrison failed to appear, but will go on duty later. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E16FD3D591373...

See also: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5126122996/] query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60E13F83C5913738... GIANT U.S. WARSHIP TAKES THE WATER; Gov. Cruce's Daughter, Half-Indian, Names the Fighting Oklahoma New York Times CAMDEN, N.J., March 23. -- "I christen thee Oklahoma," cried Miss Miss Lorena Jane Cruce, daughter of Gov. Cruce of the new western State, and as the bottle of champagne crashed smartly on the prow of the superdreadnought the cheers of patriotic Oklahomans vied with the whistles of tugs at the yards of the New York Shipbuilding Company. NOTE - If you read the full story at the link above, you will read that also present at the ill-fated USS Oklahoma's launching was "Assistant Secretary Roosevelt," that is Assistant Secretary of the Navy Franklin D. Roosevelt. Over 27 years later, USS Oklahoma would be sunk in the Japanese sneak-attack on Pearl Harbor, a day that the later-President Franklin D. Roosevelt would describe as a day which would "live in infamy."

Florence Jaffray "Daisy" Harriman (July 21, 1870 – August 31, 1967) was an American socialite, suffragist, social reformer, organizer, and later, a courageous diplomat. “She led one of the suffrage parades down Fifth Avenue, worked on campaigns on child labor and safe milk and, as minister to Norway in World War II, organized evacuation efforts while hiding in a forest from the Nazi invasion.” In her ninety-second year, U.S. President John F. Kennedy honored her by awarding her the first “Citation of Merit for Distinguished Service.” She often found herself in the middle of historic events. As she stated, “I think nobody can deny that I have always had through sheer luck. . . a box seat at the America of my times. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Jaffray_Harriman

Glenn Hammond Curtiss (May 21, 1878 – July 23, 1930) was an American aviation pioneer and a founder of the U.S. aircraft industry. He began his career as a bicycle then motorcycle builder and racer, later also manufacturing engines for airships as early as 1906. In 1908 Curtiss joined the Aerial Experiment Association (AEA), a pioneering research group founded by Alexander Graham Bell at Beinn Bhreagh, Nova Scotia to build flying machines. Curtiss rose to fame by making the country's first officially witnessed flight, winning a race at the world's first international air meet in France, and making the first long-distance flight in the U.S. His contributions in designing and building aircraft led to the formation of the Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company, now part of Curtiss-Wright Corporation. His company built aircraft for the U.S. Army and Navy, and during the years leading up to World War I, his experiments with seaplanes led to advances in naval aviation. Curtiss civil and military aircraft were predominant in the inter-war and World War II eras. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glenn_Curtiss Lieutenant Commander John Cyril Porte CMG, DSM, Royal Navy (26 February 1884 - 22 October 1919) was a flying boat pioneer associated with the World War I Seaplane Experimental Station at Felixstowe. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Cyril_Porte [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5051563150/]

Actress Elizabeth Hacker Valentine Louden was born 1877 in Brooklyn, attended Cornell, and married in 1911 to an Irishman, Thomas Louden. She was active in the suffrage movement during the 1910s, while still appearing on stage regularly, often in Shakespearean roles. In 1915, she had a role in a Broadway revival of "Our American Cousin." (She has an entry in the Women's Who's Who of America, 1914-1915; pp 501-502) Her mother, Marie Antoinette Storrs, was from a prominent Connecticut family; the Storrs family papers at UConn include some of Elizabeth Valentine's papers: doddcenter.uconn.edu/findaids/storrs/MSS20070005.html

I met Elizabeth when she just had her 90th birthday. I was just 20.  We became fast friends. When she fell and injured her hip and needed someone to stay with her so she could recover at home, I became her companion for two years.

A remarkable person and woman. I learned so much from her.

I regret that I did not have a camera handy to take what would have been a fantastic photo of her seated in front of her black and white TV watching avidly the landing on the moon. In the background was a large as life black and white framed photo of her in a period dress when she was 16.

I also regret I did not tape my conversations with her. She seemed to know so many famous people and / or was related to them!

She loved sunsets and poetry by Browning.

The day that she passed on I was sitting on a dock down near the water and there was the most gorgeous sunset. I knew she had gone. It was in her honor.

She was living at her summer home full time then, in Avondale, RI. She was still driving at 90 till her license was taken away. The neighbors called her Leadfoot Louden.

She showed me photo albums with pictures of her in old western movies. I remember seeing one of them when I was a little girl. In it she was riding in a fast moving stage coach shooting a revolver out of the window. That is all I remember. 

I have three wonderful photos of her that she gave to me. 

Dear Bessie, as her nephew called her.
Susan Jo Darling

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02]

I was too young to get to know her and living in another state, yet have always felt close to her great spirit. Today, I decided to google her for the 1st time and was pleased to find a few photos and your meaningful contribution. My father Gordon Lamb is her nephew.

Warmly,
Susanna Lamb    sannalamb@hotmail.com

Portia Willis Fitzgerald (b. c1887) was daughter of a Congressman, Col. Benjamin Willis. She was active in the suffrage movement, and was referred to as "The Prettiest Suffragette in New York State." She lectured widely and was grand marshal of several suffrage parades. She was also active in the peace movement, leading the Women's Peace Parade in 1914, and a member of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. She was active with the Red Cross during WWI. She married in 1925, to Capt. L. Rodney Berg; he died in 1941; she married a prince next; she married her third husband Gerald Fitzgerald, in 1958. Her papers are at Smith College: asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss22_mai...
No doubt named for a character in Shakespeare's play, "The Merchant of Venice": Portia, the heroine, was Shakespeare's archetype of a female lawyer.

Clara Millington Dow (29 December 1883 - 26 March 1969) was an English operatic soprano of the early twentieth century. After a concert career, she appeared at the Savoy Theatre in the first repertory seasons of Gilbert and Sullivan operas mounted by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in 1906-09, under the direction of the author. She is remembered as one of the last principal sopranos personally trained by W. S. Gilbert at the Savoy. In between engagements with D'Oyly Carte, Dow performed in concerts and operetta. Johnny Richards (b. Juan Manuel Cascales, Toluca, Mexico, 1911 – d. New York, 1968) was a noted arranger in the 1940s-'60s, with perhaps his best known work for Stan Kenton's orchestra. 

Part of a musical Mexican family that immigrated to Los Angeles, he was working as a saxophonist by 1930. As John Cascales, he featured as jazz tenor man on west coast radio programs in the mid '30s. A brother, Carlos Cascales aka Chuck Cabot, led his own orchestra starting in 1940. 

Richards joined Stan Kenton's arranging staff in 1950 and relocated to New York City by 1952, continuing to work for Kenton's band until he died of a brain tumor in 1968. He was also composer of the hit tune "Young at Heart" (1953).
Great genius. Wrote one of Kenton's greatest albums, Cuban Fire. Also the tune Young at Heart.

The man in the photograph is Alfred P. Lane, Olympic shooter and gold medalist who was hired by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) in 1914 to train police officers how to shoot.  Lane competed in two Olympics, winning three gold medals (50m Free Pistol, 50m Team Free Pistol, and 50m Rapid Fire Pistol) in the 1912 Olympic Games (Stockhom), plus a bronze medal (50m Free Pistol) and two more gold medals (50m Team Free Pistol, 50m Rapid Fire Pistol) in the 1920 Olympic Games (Antwerp).   Lane would later be among the first inducted into the United States International Shooters Hall of Fame in 1991.

Also of interest in this photograph is the pistol Lane is shooting.  It is a Colt Model 1908 Hammerless Pistol (Colt M1908), designed by John Moses Browning, and manufactured by Colt.  It is noteworthy because during this period the NYPD became one of the few police departments of the era to have adopted a semi-automatic pistol as an issued firearm (in this case for its detectives.)  However, the M1908's career in the NYPD was short lived, and it was withdrawn from NYPD service by 1918 (thought to be because of accidental/negligent discharges by some of the officers it was issued to).  The NYPD would not authorize the widespread issue of semi-automatic pistols again until 1993.

The text in German is Der Flieger Karl Ingold, der durch einen Flug von 16 Stunden 20 Minuten einen neuen Weltrekord im Überlandflug ohne Zwischenlandung aufstellte; er stieg am 08. Februar [1914] morgens in Mülhausen i. E. auf, flog über Gotha, Naumburg, Kottbus und die Lausitz, bog dann nach Süden bis Kempten und landete schließlich nachts 11,55 bei München. Er erhielt für seinen 1700-km-Flug den Städtepreis der Nationalflugspende. Bruno Langers Weltrekord wird durch den Flug Ingolds nicht beeinträchtigt, da eine Dauerhöchstleistung nur auf dem Flugplatz vor den Augen der Sportzeugen gewertet wird. Karl Ingold obtained German flying license (Flugzeugführer) No.114 on 13 September 1911.

Ingold was in the news already in 1913 when he made another short overland flight on 26 September 1913. This is the (small) report as published in Flugsport

Von Mülhausen (Elsaß) nach Leipzig flog am 26. September Ingolf auf Aviatik-Eindecker 100 PS Argus-Motor in 6 Studen. Er flog in Mülhausen am 6 Uhr morgens ab und landete um 12 Uhr mittages in Leipzig auf dem Flugplatz Mockau. Gegen 4 Uhr ist er nach Johannisthal aufgestiegen, wo er 4 1/2 Uhr eintraf.

Source: Flugsport 1913 - Issue 20 (1 October)  p.767

She's quite an interesting historical figure. Henriette Caillaux was a murderer, and the wife of the Finance Minister of France. Her husband's reputation was sullied by the editor of Le Figaro, who had printed the private correspondence of the minister, parts of which suggested improprieties while in office. In defense of her husband, Mme. Caillaux went to the editor's office, pulled out a pistol, and shot him three times in the chest, killing him instantly. Her trial was big news in the year 1914. Remarkably, she was acquitted on the basis that the murder was not premeditated but an overwhelming emotional response which she (being a woman) could not have controlled. # https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/Henriette_Caillaux

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM COMPANY:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

possibly this is Charlotte Louise Juliette Grimaldi. A political crisis loomed for Louis II, Prince of Monaco because without any other heir, the throne of Monaco would pass to his first cousin Wilhelm, the duke of Urach, a German nobleman who was a son of Prince Albert's aunt, Princess Florestine of Monaco. To ensure this did not happen, in 1911 a law was passed recognizing his bastard daughter, Charlotte, as Louis's acknowledged heir, and making her part of the sovereign family. This law was later held to be invalid under the 1882 statutes. Thus another law was passed in 1918 modifying the statutes to allow the adoption of an heir, with succession rights. Charlotte was formally adopted by Louis in 1919, and became Charlotte Louise Juliette Grimaldi, Princess of Monaco, and Duchess of Valentinois. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Charlotte,_Duchess_of_Vale...

Thanks, everyone, for your comments.  It does, indeed, appear that this is a photo of Alice Heine taken much earlier.  An article in McClure's Magazine (May 1924), p. 57, includes a front-facing portrait of her from later in her life, and the features seem to match.  Other biographical details I gathered along the way from this article and one in Town & Country (Feb. 8, 1913): She was the daughter of New Orleans banker Michael Heine.  She married Armand de Jumilhac at age 16 and became the duchesse de Richelieu two years later when he inherited the title.  She was a widow with two children by age 24, and she married Prince Albert of Monaco in 1889.  They divorced in 1902, and because of a prenuptial agreement she sacrificed a large part of her fortune to her husband when they parted ways.

We'll add some information to the description when we next update to identify her and indicate that the portrait was likely from an earlier photograph.

wonderful. This is after the outbreak of the WWI, Aug 1914, as her funnels have already been painted all black, and they were repainted back to her original color again sometime in the fall. In 1915 when she was sunk it is generally believed they were still the original color. You can see she is high in the water, indicating this is the end of the trip as coal and supplies have been used up. This photo is attributed to 1914 based on the visible modifications. You can see the list of them here. titanic-model.com/articles/lusi_tutoria/LUSITANIA_Tutoria... things you can see: the number of life boats, the replaced ventilation caps,and the paint scheme.

that's interesting because the funnels certainly appear to be a single color.  The red  may be harder to distinguish from the black top quarter, but this photo shows no discernible difference on the funnel unlike below and above the waterline. .  War broke out in August, so there should be no reason why it would be solid colored already in March.  It makes you wonder if the photo could have been tampered with in some way or if for some reason lost to history the funnels would have been painted early in the year, or these lighting conditions just make them appear uniform.

LOC --- you have a double typo: you have misspelled Wilson, and "Carlile" has no ESS.

He was the founder of the "Church Army," the Anglican church's mission to working-class Englishmen (who felt excluded from organized religion because of British society's rigid class structure). (The CA was the official Church of England's answer to the Salvation Army, which had been founded four years earlier, and was regarded by the church as a renegade outfit.) Carlile (note the odd spelling) was in the news at the time in 1914 when Bain circulated this photo to his subscribers, having been received by King George V at Buckingham Palace, on February 13, 1914. PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH MUTUAL FILM CO.:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes Charles Gates Dawes (August 27, 1865 – April 23, 1951) was an American banker and politician who was the 30th Vice President of the United States. For his work on the Dawes Plan for World War I reparations he was a co-recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize. He served in the First World War, was U.S. Comptroller of the Currency, the first director of the Bureau of the Budget, and, in later life, the U.S. Ambassador to the United Kingdom.
Dawes was Calvin Coolidge's Vice President, but it was not a happy marriage: they despised each other.
Plus, he wrote either the lyrics or music to the popular music classic "It's All In The Game"

Dawes composed the tune, which for years was known as the "Dawes Melody" or "Melody in A Major." In 1951, at the request of Warner Brothers records, Tommy Edwards wrote lyrics for the tune, altering it somewhat and giving it a name. (Coincidentally, Dawes died in that year, never getting to hear the Edwards version.) Soon after, "It's All in The Game" became a No. 1 hit. www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=2145

This is the armored cruiser USS New York (ACR-2), of Spanish-American War fame, later renamed the USS Saratoga, then the USS Rochester in 1917.

This ship was commissioned as New York (ACR-2) in 1893. She was renamed Saratoga in 1911 to make the name New York available for BB-34. Her name was changed again to Rochester in 1917 to free the name for the cruiser CC-3 which was completed as the second US Navy aircraft carrier CV-3. Rochester was decommissioned in 1933 and remained moored in Subic Bay, Phillipines until she was scuttled in December 1941 to prevent her capture by Japanese forces.

Hulbert was born in Rochester, New York on May 14, 1881 and moved to Waterloo, New York, where he attended the public schools. He was graduated from the New York Law School; was admitted to the bar in 1902 and practiced law in New York City; elected as a Democrat to the Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Congresses and served from March 4, 1915, to January 1, 1918, when he resigned to become Commissioner of Docks and director of the port of New York City; elected president of the Board of Aldermen of New York City in November 1921 and served as acting mayor during the long illness of Mayor Hylan; president of the Boston, Cape Cod & New York Canal; resumed the practice of law until June 1934, when he was appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt as district judge to the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, in which capacity he served until his death in Bayport, Long Island.[1] He was buried in Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York. William Hesketh Lever, 1st Viscount Leverhulme, Bt, (19 September 1851 – 7 May 1925) was an English Industrialist, philanthropist and colonialist. Lever personified the Northern, nonconformist conscience: he was Liberal in his politics, earnest in his philanthropic endeavors, and committed to social amelioration and moral improvement at home, as typified by Lever’s company town, Port Sunlight. Although attacked for his labor policies in palm oil plantations in the Congo, he was committed to Britain’s “civilizing mission” overseas.[1] Starting with a small grocery business begun by his father, he began making soap in the 1880s. Lever rode the cresting late-Victorian consumer revolution to build a vast industrial empire spread across the globe, with such famous brands as Lux and Lifebuoy. Four years after his death his enterprises were amalgamated as Unilever, which, by 1930, employed a quarter of a million people and, in terms of market value, was the largest company in Britain

Franz Ferdinand (18 December 1863 – 28 June 1914) was an Archduke of Austria-Este, Austro-Hungarian and Royal Prince of Hungary and of Bohemia, and from 1889 until his death, heir presumptive to the Austro-Hungarian throne. His assassination in Sarajevo precipitated Austria-Hungary's declaration of war against Serbia. This caused Germany and Austria-Hungary, and countries allied with Serbia (the Triple Entente Powers) to declare war on each other, starting World War I.

Margarethe Arndt-Ober (1885–1971) was an American opera singer of German descent who had an active international career during the first half of the twentieth century. A highly skilled contralto[1], Ober enjoyed a particularly long and fruitful association with the Berlin State Opera from 1907 to 1944. She also was notably a principal singer at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City between 1913 and 1917. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margarethe_Arndt-Ober

Lavinia "Vinnie" Ream Hoxie (1847-1914) was a sculptor, first woman to win a commission from the US Government to create a statue (of Lincoln, after his assassination): she also sculpted portraits of Admiral Farragut and Sequoyah. Apparently the Bain News Service circulated this photo of Ream-Hoxie to its clients at the time of her death -- January 12, 1914. She is buried in Arlington National Cemetery. And the town of Vinita, Oklahoma, was named in her honor (although she was a Wisconsin native).

Sir Henry Worth Thornton, KBE (6 November 1871 in Logansport, Indiana – 14 March 1933 in New York City) was a businessman and president of Canadian National Railways. His parents were Henry Clay Thornton and Millamenta Comegys Worth. Henry W. Thornton married Virginia D. Blair, from a prominent Pittsburgh family, on June 20, 1901; They had two children: James Worth Thornton and Anna Blair Thornton (Harrison). In 1926 Sir Henry divorced Lady Blair Thornton. He remarried shortly thereafter to Martha Watriss, daughter of prominent attorney and Nassau County Commissioner Frederick N. Watriss. Thornton was General Superintendent of the Long Island Rail Road from 1911 to 1914 and General Manager of the Great Eastern Railway in England from 1914 to 1922. From 1922 to 1932, he was the President of the Canadian National Railways. Thornton played college football at the University of Pennsylvania and served as the head coach of the football team at Vanderbilt University for one season in 1894. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Henry_Worth_Thornton

Jacob Sechler Coxey Sr. sometimes known as General Coxey (April 16, 1854 – May 18, 1951) of Massillon, Ohio, was a socialist American politician, who ran for elective office several times in Ohio. He twice led Coxey's Army (in 1894 and 1914), bands of unemployed men, on marches from Massillon to Washington, D.C. to present a "Petition in Boots" demanding that the United States Congress appropriate money to create jobs for the unemployed. Although his march failed, Coxey's Army was a harbinger of an issue that would rise to prominence as unemployment insurance would become a key element in the future Social Security Act. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_S._Coxey,_Sr.

Félix Díaz Velasco (17 February 1868 – 9 July 1945) was a Mexican politician and general born in Oaxaca, Oaxaca. He graduated as an engineer from the Colegio Militar in 1888. This Matzene photo was probably taken some time before his death, From www.buffaloah.com/h/butler/ "[Edward Hubert] Butler was born in Leroy in 1850. He was educated in the public schools and by private tutors. As a teenager he worked for the Leroy Gazette, then was city editor first of the Scranton Times, then of the Post. At twenty-two he took his savings to Buffalo and in 1873 came out with his own paper, the Buffalo Sunday News, which was a success. On October 11, 1880, his weekday paper, the Buffalo Evening News, came out and sold more than 7,000 copies on the street alone. It cost only a cent, whereas most contemporary dailies cost two or three cents. Circulation boomed to 20,000, and soon the News enjoyed the largest circulation of any paper between New York and Chicago. [In 1896, a new building was built for the newspaper operations at 218 Main St.] Butler was given to leading crusades, including discipline at the Elmira Reformatory, enlargement of the Erie Canal, and a new building for the State Normal School in Buffalo. He was an original member of the Grade Crossing Commission and continued on it for twenty-six years. He never ran for public office but was a dominant figure in the state G.O.P. His wife was Mary E. Barber of Pittston, Pennsylvania, who died in 1893. Two children survived their father, one of whom, Edward H. Butler, Jr., succeeded when Edward, I, died in 1914. "

The Reverend Hannibal Goodwin (1822–1900), an Episcopal priest at the House of Prayer in Newark, New Jersey, patented a method for making transparent, flexible roll film out of nitrocellulose film base, which was used in Thomas Edison's Kinetoscope, an early machine for viewing animation. He was motivated to search for a non-breakable, and clear substance on which he could place the images he utilized in his Biblical teachings. George Eastman was no doubt a member of the audience during this time. In May 2, 1887, the year Reverend Goodwin retired from the church he had served for twenty years, he filed a patent for "a photographic pellicle and process of producing same . . . . especially in connection with roller cameras", but the patent was not granted until 13 September 1898. Patent number: 610861. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hannibal_Goodwin The patent dispute filed against Kodak was settled on March 27, 1914, even though he had died in 1900, 14 years earlier.

Everyone I knew in jazz who knew Benny told me he was tough to work for, a perfectionist.  They said he was not very nice to people.  Sorry, but that is what many have told me.  However, he put together some great bands.  That recording of the 1938 Carnegie Hall concert is still one of the greatest Big Band albums ever made.

I've heard the very same from others who have worked with him.

To say he was a perfectionist is merely another way of saying he was a true artist. I'm an artist,  and I'm rather particular about my work. I wont be satisfied till it meets my standards… We have our minds made up as to how we want things, how things are to look and to sound. Goodman was indeed this type. As to him not being kind may have mostly been a frustration with whipping musicians into shape, other musicians are artists too so, there's where other styles and ideas collide. Benny was the leader of the band so, I can see where he could get grumpy with others. 

I've heard accounts from first daughter that he'd get frustrated when helping her with her own musical endeavors. His patience wore thin from time to time, and he'd insist she practice the piano to perfect her skill… but, at the end she knew he loved her and only wanted her to succeed.

I am a perfectionist also in certain things.  I am a perfectionist when ti comes to photography.  I am a perfectionist in my writings.  I am a perfectionist in making prints.  But, I do think a person can be a "true artist" and not be a perfectionist.  Perfectionism often stifles art and life in general.  An artist, for example, could spend a lifetime on one piece of art.  Is that good?  Maybe, maybe not.  Some things that are "perfect" are not my idea my idea of art.  

One thing I liked about Goodman was that he would not put up with guys doing drugs.  Although drugs may have stirred creativity in musicians, they also spelled the ends of many careers.  If I were a band leader, I wouldn't want drug users in my band, either.  If you want to do drugs, fine, that's up to you....but you won't be in my band.  Or on my baseball team.  Or my business or personal partner.

Long live Benny Goodman's music.

Rufus Isaacs, 1st Marquess of Reading, GCB, GCSI, GCIE, GCVO, PC, KC (10 October 1860 – 30 December 1935), was an English lawyer, jurist and politician. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rufus_Isaacs,_1st_Marquess_of_Reading
Splendid view. Thanks and regards.
The whole business with the white wigs on the European aristocracy always puzzled me.

Generally speaking, this wig would be a symbol of his Judicial office. In British Courts, generally, wigs are also worn by Barristers-At-Law, who appear representing the prosecution or the defence in court. Barristers' wigs do not have the long sides depicted here. Nor do Barristers wear the type of robe depicted here. Isaacs was appointed Lord Chief Justice, 2nd most senior law officer ( roughly the equivalent of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the USA) in 1913. Although I am not expert in legal regalia, I believe the chain he is wearing in this photograph is part of the regalia associated with the Office of Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales (e.g. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayner_Goddard,_Baron_Goddard )
straight pimp.
He was made a peer in the New Year's Honours List of 1914.  This was expected after his appointment as Lord Chef Justice and  would have made him a "law lord" in the House of Lords.

That particular collar of office or livery collar is known as a Collar of Esses, for the S-shapes in the design. According to Christie's, "These collars of office became the personal property of each Lord Chief Justice and were subsequently sold, upon the office-holder's retirement, to the incoming occupier of the post." Christie's also says that when the office of Lord Chief Justice of England was created in 1880 from the merging of two other offices, a new chain of office was made; presumably that 1880 chain is the one we see here, as well as on the current Lord Chief Justice in this photo. Not sure if the wig & coat are also passed down, but presumably Isaacs' coat was also scarlet in color.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honus_Wagner Johannes Peter "Honus" Wagner (February 24, 1874 – December 6, 1955), nicknamed The Flying Dutchman due to his superb speed and German heritage ("Dutch" in this instance being an alteration of "Deutsch"), was an American Major League Baseball shortstop who played in the National League from 1897 to 1917, almost entirely for the Pittsburgh Pirates. Wagner won eight batting titles, tied for the most in NL history with Tony Gwynn. He also led the league in slugging six times, and in stolen bases five times. In 1936, the Baseball Hall of Fame inducted Wagner as one of the first five members. He received the second-highest vote total, behind Ty Cobb and tied with Babe Ruth. Although Cobb is frequently cited as the greatest player of the dead-ball era, some contemporaries regarded Wagner as the better all-around player, and most baseball historians consider Wagner to be the greatest shortstop ever. Cobb himself called Wagner "maybe the greatest star ever to take the diamond."

These are my personal thoughts, not simply stuff copied and pasted from the Internet:
Wagner was the greatest shortstop of his era, but defensively he would never stack up against Luis Aparicio, Ozzie Smith, and any of about 20 shortstops since Ozzie.  Shortstops in the old days never had the range and arms of today's stars.  I would say Leo Durocher, PeeWee Reese, Phil Rizzuto, Chico Carasquel, Don Kessinger, and even Ernie Banks were all better defensively than Wagner, too.  But, you have to compare players against their peers, and there was no one as good as Wagner in his era.  

 It is true that one of the reasons dead ball era shortstops did not have the range they have today is that their gloves were pretty much useless unless the player could get his bare hand to cover the ball, in other words use both hands, to catch it.  It was hard to reach out and catch a ball with a glove that had no web or lacing between the fingers and was built flat versus the more modern gloves which are curved and have nice webs.  Also, infields of artificial turf don't create bad hops except very occasionally when the ball hits a seem or edge.  The ball moves faster, so it is easier for it to get through a hole.  However, it also gets to the fielder quicker so that he can make the throw in time to usually get the runner.  

We don't see the number of infield hits that occurred during the high grass and dead ball era.  This is one of the reasons batting averages were higher among good hitters in the old days. Guys like Wagner got a substanital number of bunt hits because of the high grass.  The dead ball era obviously came to an end with Babe Ruth.  Coincidence or just his sheer power?  Well, remember,Ruth was the only one for a few years who hit a ton of homeruns, so it was his sheer power.  But, gradually, balls were wound tighter and went farther.  Also, Ruth never choked up on his bat which gave him more power.  Wagner always choked up on the bat and that helped him accumulate 3,435 lifetime hits in 21 years.  Ruth had 2,873 hits in 22 years.  Both Wagner and Ruth were in that elete first class of 8 in the Hall of Fame in 1936.  We read and hear of Babe Ruth all the time, but, frankly Honus Wagner today is most remembered for having his picture on the most valuable baseball card of all time.

Honus Wagner (Johannes Peter Wagner: 1874–1955) was honored with this 33¢ US commemorative stamp in 2000 as part of the Classic Collections: Legends of Baseball issue. The Legends of Baseball issue honored 20 baseball greats who were named to the "All-Century Team," announced after the 1999 season. Votes from fans, as well as members of a special panel, selected the team.
"These players embody the glory and tradition of our national past-time. Tales of their extraordinary abilities and larger-than-life personalities have made them much more than just ballplayers: THEY ARE LEGENDS. “The Pittsburgh Pirates’ star shortstop, Honus Wagner also was a league-leading batter and base stealer. The ‘Flying Dutchman’ enjoyed 15 consecutive .300 seasons, 8 as the National League batting champ.” – From the back of the sheet of stamps.
After his retirement from baseball, Wagner coached several teams, including the Pirates from 1933 to 1951. He also owned a sporting goods store with fellow player Pie Traynor. In 1936, Honus Wagner was one of the first five players elected to the Hall of Fame. First Day of Issue ceremonies were held July 6, 2000, in Atlanta, Georgia, where Major League Baseball held the 2000 All Star Week and 2000 All Star Game. (Scott 3408c). (A matching 20¢ US Postal Card (Scott UX353) was also issued at the same time.)

The Translantic Flyer "America" was built by Glenn H. Curtiss on Keuka Lake, near Hammondsport, New York. The project was underwritten by Rodman Wanamaker, of the Wanamaker department store chain of Philadelphia and New York City, who hoped to claim the $50,000 prize posted by Lord Northcliffe, of the London Daily Mail, for the first airplane flight from England to North America, or from N.A. to England. The "America" had a 72-foot wingspan. The outbreak of World War I in August, 1914, caused the project to be aborted. The first trans-Atlantic airplane flight was made in 1919, using a different aircraft.

The Dutch call those wooden shoes "Klompen," a word which I suspect is an example of onomatopoeia.

Possibly, the word "klomp" is related to the English "clump", both meaning a heap or formless mass. The Dutch dictionary claims that the wooden shoe "klomp" is derived from the formless-mass meaning because the shoe is made from a clump of wood.

It is still worn today, usually in the rural parts of the Netherlands.

Christopher "Christy" Mathewson (August 12, 1880 – October 7, 1925), nicknamed "Big Six", "The Christian Gentleman", or "Matty", was an American right-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball. He played in what is known as the dead-ball era; and in 1936 was elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame as one of its "first five" inaugural members. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christy_Mathewson

What I think is amazing is that he won 373 games in just 17 seasons, still tied for the most lifetimes wins in the NL with Grover Alexander.  During WWI, he was accidentally gassed with mustard gas and damaged his lungs, leaving him open to TB.  He never was the same after that.

Pennsylvania politician Vance Criswell McCormick (1872-1946), was running for governor of Pennsylvania in 1914. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vance_C._McCormick

Here's what a fellow native of Harrisburg PA says about Harrisburg's favorite son, Vance Criswell McCormick:

By  LEON L CZIKOWSKY (Harrisburg, Pa USA) 

This review is from: "Citizen Extraordinaire: The Diplomatic Diaries of Vance McCormick in London and Paris, 1917-1919: With Other Documents from a High-Minded American Life" 

This book is a collection of articles written about, and diary entries during the diplomatic years of, Vance McCormick, a "citizen extraordinaire." Vance McCormick was an All American football star at Yale, Mayor of Harrisburg, Democratic National Chairman during Woodrow Wilson's 1916 reelection campaign, a diplomat under President Wilson, and unsuccessful candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania. The bulk of this book concentrates on the diplomatic years of Vance McCormick, as he served during the times leading to our entry in World War I through the war years and he was at a participant at the peace talks. 

It is interesting reading how the editor and Penn State Harrisburg students went through nine boxes of family letters and documents to compile this book. Students of local history may wish to note that Vance McCormick was a director of the Central Iron and Steel Works which used to be located in the southern part of Harrisburg, that he was elected to City Council and then, in 1902, as Mayor as a reform Democrat, and then went on to own the Harrisburg Patriot newspaper and found the Evening News, which lasted until a few years ago. 

American History scholars will find the bulk of this book as an insight into one diplomat's perspective of our effort to conduct a blockade of German ships during the First World War and of various missions before and after the war. Football fans may find it interesting to note that Vance McCormick was an All American quarterback on an 1892 Yale team that outscored its opponents by 435 to 0, but that McCormick scored none of those points. In football then, players played both offense and defense, and McCormick was noted for his defensive skills and his leadership at quarterback during a time when quarterbacks seldom scored goals. 

The set of Vance McCormick diary entries during 1917, when he led the War Trade Board, fail to provide the perspectives that later diary entries provide. He would write comments such as "we made some progress, but not as much as I had hoped" without describing the circumstances of the discussions that would have proven more enlightening to future generations of readers. Still, his notations that he was impressed with the commitment the British had for the war allows us to realize that the American government was impressed that America could eventually successfully serve as a British ally. 

Later diary entries, after the United States entered the war, are more vibrant. His descriptions of the miles of destruction around Verdun, site of the war's most devastating battlefield, are among highlights found in these diaries. We learn about his concern during the peace talks about the sinking condition of the German people and his concern about the imperialism and militarism expressed by the war victors. Vance McCormick thought it was ridiculous of Lloyd George of England to promise the British people he would extract $120 billion in war reparations from Germany as Germany had no ability to pay anywhere close to that amount. This becomes of historic interest as he may have perceived the dangers that many historians believe ultimately led to the German resentment that led to World War II. Further, Vance McCormick expressed concern over blockades of Poland, Estonia, Lettland, and Lithuania, which the British supported, fearing that the blockade would allow these countries to fall to Russia. Of special note is his concern that the Germans might not accept the peace agreement as there were fears the French and English armies could no longer continue to battle the German army and that, should the peace talks collapse, it would be left for the American army to fight the German army. 

The book notes that Vance McCormick placed his opinions above political party loyalty. He refused, as a supporter of prohibition, to support anti-prohibition Democratic nominees for President in 1928 and for Governor in 1930. Dauphin County Democrats then ousted a party slate run by McCormick. 

Reading diary entries of a diplomat may be boring to many, but they serve an important historical purpose. Reviving insights into these historical moments maintains our awareness and connections to our past. It has been reported that, in 2004, the last known surviving combat wounded American veteran of World War I passed away. There are historians who observe that we could have learned from World War I the mistakes that led to World War II. Let us not let this history dissolve. This book is just one small part into keeping this history alive.

Wilfrid Ward, the staunchly Roman Catholic editor of the Dublin Review, late in 1913 was on a speaking tour of the United States. The tour may still have been in progress in January, 1914, when the Bain News Agency circulated this photograph to its subscribers. At his December 5, 1913, lecture in New York City (attended by prominent Catholics, including Cardinal John Farley of New York), Ward spoke in praise of the late British scholar and Cardinal, John Henry Newman. Report in the New York Times, December 6, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=980CEFD61E3BE633A...

Wilfrid Ward's daughter, Maisie, married an Australian, Frank Sheed, and in 1926 they founded the now well-known British Catholic publishing house of Sheed & Ward, which has a branch in the U. S. www.jstor.org/pss/25154864

The celebrated author Wilfrid Sheed is the son of Frank and Maisie, and the grandson of Wilfrid Ward. Among his numerous published volumes is a biography of his parents. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilfrid_Sheed

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Irene_of_Hesse_and_by_Rhine Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine (Irene Luise Maria Anna) (11 July 1866 – 11 November 1953) was the third child and third daughter of Princess Alice of the United Kingdom and Ludwig IV, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine. Her maternal grandparents were Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom and Prince Albert. Her paternal grandparents were Prince Charles of Hesse and by Rhine and Princess Elizabeth of Prussia. She was the wife of Prince Albert Wilhelm Heinrich of Prussia, her first cousin. Like her sister Alix, Irene was a carrier of the haemophilia gene. Two of her three sons were haemophiliacs. Her younger sister, Alix, become the Tsarina Alexandra Feodorovna of their paternal second cousin Tsar Nicholas II of Russia. Her younger brother, Ernst, became Grand Duke of Hesse. Her eldest sister Victoria married their father's morganatic first cousin, Prince Louis of Battenberg (later Marquess and Marchioness of Milford Haven). Another sister Elizabeth, (later canonized by the Russian Orthodox Church as St.Elizabeth the Martyr) married their father's first cousin, Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia.

Her husband was AKA  "Prince Henry of Prussia", which is why she's labeled this way.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Schweninger Ernst Schweninger (1850–1924) was a German physician, born in Freystadt, Upper Palatinate. He studied medicine at Munich (M.D., 1870) and for some years was in practice. His appointment to a chair at Berlin (1884) (against the wishes of the medical faculty) was largely due to his successful treatment of Bismarck for obesity. His method was a modified Banting. He retired to private life in Munich in 1905. Schweninger wrote Dem Andenken Bismarcks (1899).

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Griffith_Haight Thomas Griffith Haight (August 4, 1879 - January 26, 1942) was a United States federal judge in New Jersey. Born in Freehold Township, New Jersey, Haight was educated at Princeton University and earned an LL.B from New York Law School in 1900. He was in private practice from 1901 to 1913, although briefly serving as the city attorney for Jersey City, New Jersey. Haight was nominated by President Woodrow Wilson to a seat vacated by Joseph Cross on the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, on February 3, 1914. He was confirmed by the United States Senate on February 18, 1914, and received his commission that day. On April 1, 1919, Wilson elevated Haight to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit through a recess appointment, to a seat vacated by John Bayard McPherson. Haight was formally nominated on May 23, 1919 and confirmed by the Senate on June 24, 1919, receiving his commission that day. However, he resigned on May 31, 1920, returning to private practice until his death.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Stanley,_17th_Earl_of_Derby Edward George Villiers Stanley, 17th Earl of Derby KG, GCB, GCVO, TD, PC, KGStJ, JP (4 April 1865 – 4 February 1948), known as Lord Stanley from 1893 to 1908, was a British soldier, Conservative politician, diplomat and racehorse owner. He was twice Secretary of State for War and also served as British Ambassador to France.

Lord Derby was in the news in February 1914 because he appeared to be offering to sell a family estate for a large amount and was being cited as an example of untaxed income on the capital gain. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Van_Schaick_Cochrane Aaron Van Schaick Cochrane (March 14, 1858 - September 7, 1943) was a U.S. Representative from New York, nephew of Isaac Whitbeck Van Schaick. Born in Coxsackie, New York, Cochrane attended the common schools and the Hudson River Institute at Claverack, New York. He graduated from Yale College in 1879. He moved to Hudson, New York, in 1879, where he studied law. He was admitted to the bar in 1881 and commenced practice in Hudson, New York. He served as city judge of Hudson in 1887 and 1888. He served as district attorney of Columbia County 1889-1892. Cochrane was elected as a Republican to the Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Congresses (March 4, 1897-March 3, 1901). He was not a candidate for renomination in 1900, but was elected associate justice of the Supreme Court of New York in 1901. He was reelected in 1915 for the term ending in 1928, designated by Governor Nathan Lewis Miller presiding justice of the appellate division of the State supreme court in 1922. Cochrane retired from the bench in 1928 but served as official referee until 1941. He died in Hudson, New York, September 7, 1943. He was interred in Riverside Cemetery, Coxsackie, New York.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Friedrich_Karl_of_Prussia_(1... Prince Friedrich Karl von Preußen was born in Schloss Klein-Glienicke, Potsdam/Berlin. He was the son of Prince Friedrich Leopold of Prussia (1865-1931) and Princess Louise Sophie of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Augustenburg (1866-1952) and a grandson of Prince Frederick Charles of Prussia. He was part of the German team, which was able to win a bronze medal in the equestrian team jumping event. His horse during the Olympic competition was "Gibson Boy". He fought in World War I between 1914 and 1917. He commanded FA(A)258, but flew patrols in a single seat fighter with Jasta Boelcke whenever possible. During one such patrol on March 21, 1917 he was forced to land with a bullet in his engine and a slight wound to his foot. He landed his Albatros aircraft in no-man's land, but while running towards his own lines he was severely wounded in the back by Australian troops. He was taken into Australian war captivity where he died from his injuries on April 6, 1917 at Saint-Étienne-du-Rouvray.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Henry,_Duke_of_Gloucester The Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester (Henry William Frederick Albert; 31 March 1900 – 10 June 1974) was a member of the British Royal Family, the third son of George V of the United Kingdom and Queen Mary, and thus uncle to Elizabeth II. He was appointed potential regent for his niece, when his brother (George VI) came to the throne in 1936, and was required to stay in the United Kingdom until she came of age in case her father died and she ascended the throne under age. The Duke served as the 11th Governor-General of Australia, from 1945 to 1947. At his death, he was the last surviving knight of the Order of St. Patrick.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Caminetti He was born in Jackson, Amador County, California. He attended the public schools of his native county, the grammar schools in San Francisco, and the University of California, Berkeley. He also studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1877 and commenced practice in Jackson. He was the district attorney of Amador County from 1878 until 1882. Caminetti served in the California State Assembly in 1883–1885. He was also a member of the State Senate from 1885 to 1887. He was elected as a Democrat to the Fifty-second and Fifty-third Congresses (March 4, 1891 – March 3, 1895). He was an unsuccessful candidate in 1894 for reelection to the Fifty-fourth Congress. He was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1896 and again a member of the State assembly from 1897 until 1901. In April 1897, he was appointed code commissioner and served until July 31, 1899. He was member of the State Senate from 1907 to 1913 and served as United States commissioner general of immigration from 1913 to 1921. As immigration chief he displayed a naked Eurocentic xenophobia and argued that the U.S. Congress should end all immigration of Chinese, Japanese and Malays because they represented the "Asiatic menace." In 1917, he was appointed a member of the War Industries Board and after the war was sent to Europe to investigate conditions there. He engaged in the practice of law in Jackson until his death in 1923. He was buried in the Protestant Cemetery.

Thanks for the information, Richard Arthur Norton.  We'll fill in the name next time we update the record.

It figures that Caminetti came from California, the only part of the country much affected by Chinese immigration during his lifetime. Cheap Chinese labor built the western end of the Union Pacific Railroad, but California's native workingmen resented Asians' competition for jobs. As a result of agitation by California politicos, President Rutherford B. Hayes in 1880 appointed James B. Angell, president of the University of Michigan here in Ann Arbor, as Ambassador Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to China, to negotiate a treaty which curtailed, but did not entirely prohibit, what had been viewed as a "flood" of cheap Chinese labor. Angell managed the delicate task, but after he returned to the U. S. in 1881, Congress negated his efforts by passing the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, which slammed the door shut. 

While Angell and his wife were in China, they were charmed by the educated Chinese that they met, and invited them to enroll their children at the University of Michigan. A University regent, Levi L. Barbour, established a scholarship program here for Chinese women.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_S._West William Stanley West (August 23, 1849 – December 22, 1914) was a United States Senator from the state of Georgia. He was a Democrat.
bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=W000305
A few days after the 1914-2-26 date written on this negative, West was appointed to the Senate.  In November 1914 he returned to being a "planter and lumberman."  In December 1914, he died.

In March 1914 the Governor of Georgia appointed West U. S. Senator, to fill out the unexpired term of Senator Augustus O. Bacon, who had died. West did not run for election to the office in November, 1914, and retired in that month after the election of a successor.) His death on December 22 was unexpected, as he had been in good health. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddie_Collins Edward Trowbridge Collins, Sr. (May 2, 1887 – March 25, 1951), nicknamed "Cocky", was an American second baseman, manager and executive in Major League Baseball who played from 1906 to 1930 for the Philadelphia Athletics and Chicago White Sox. At the end of his career, he ranked second in major league history in career games (2,826), walks (1,499) and stolen bases (744), third in runs scored (1,821), fourth in hits (3,315) and at bats (9,949), sixth in on base percentage (.424), and eighth in total bases (4,268); he was also fourth in AL history in triples (187). He still holds the major league record of 512 career sacrifice hits, over 100 more than any other player. He was the first major leaguer in modern history to steal 80 bases in a season, and still shares the major league record of six steals in a game, which he accomplished twice in September 1912. He regularly batted over .320, retiring with a career average of .333. He also holds major league records for career games (2,650), assists (7,630) and total chances (14,591) at second base, and ranks second in putouts (6,526). Under the win shares statistical rating system created by baseball historian and analyst Bill James, Collins was the greatest second baseman of all time.

Hmm.  Bain's archivist is crossing us up again.  The photo is dated 1914 as wystan notes, and that's a Chicago uniform, but Collins didn't play for the White Sox until the 1915 season (http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/collied01.shtml ) and that photo obviously wasn't taken in Feb.  

Collins would probably be a lot more famous if he hadn't played in the same era with Ty Cobb.

To make things more mysterious, the sequence number 29807-10 (whatever that means) is in order with the photo before and after it, so it appears to be in the right place in the collection.

But on closer inspection of the full size photo -- I don't think that's Eddie.  Putting the wrong name on the photo would explain the other apparent errors.
That's the ticket: this is Shano Collins. Compare: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3201064665/

Excellent work, rjones! And this is not the first time that we have discovered a screw-up in LOC's labeling of one of Bain's baseball player photos, as a result of sloppy work by the "Pictorial History committee of the Society for American Baseball Research."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustave_F._Touchard He was born in New York on January 11, 1888. At the US Nationals, Touchard paired with Raymond D. Little to win the 1911 doubles title and reach the 1912 doubles final. At the tournament now known as the Cincinnati Masters, Touchard won the 1912 singles title over Richard H. Palmer. He reached the singles final in 1913 losing to William S. McEllroy. He won the National Indoor title three consecutive years (1913, 1914 & 1915) and won the singles title at the New Jersey state championship in 1915. In 1912, he reached the final of the US Clay Court Championship, losing to Richard Norris Williams. He joined the Royal Air Force. He died in 1918 in Toronto General Hospital of a throat operation. His opponent: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4909923217/in/set-72157603624867509/]

"46: This was the address of Automatic Vaudeville, a penny arcade opened in 1903 by Adolph Zukor, who later founded Paramount, with the backing of Marcus Loew; it featured penny-operated peeps, phonograph listening stations, stationary bikes, punching bags and a shooting gallery in the basement. When projected movies came in, the establishment added Crystal Hall, a cinema that was reached via a glass staircase that contained a simulated waterfall and colored lights. Charlie Chaplin films played nearly continuously there from 1914 to 1923, when a fire gutted the interior; no one was hurt, but the complex was converted to retail, becoming Orbach's; apparently some of the original building is still incorporated into the present structure. "  (www.nysonglines.com)
