PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH MUTUAL FILM CO.:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

the sculpture is from Henry Moore : probably "Reclining figure", 1939

Moore did many variations on "Reclining Figure." MOMA appears to have a 1938 version of Reclining Figure in cast lead (but does not show an image online). This does not look like lead to me. A 1939 version in elmwood (which looks very much like the image in the Bain photo in shape and is now in the Detroit Institute of Arts) is seen at www.henry-moore.org/works-in-public/world/united-states-o... www.theartsdesk.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item... shows a number of Reclining Figure variations, made over a long period, and in a variety of materials.

Looking at the hi-res TIFF, the Moore sculpture is definitely wood. So maybe the piece currently in Detroit was at MoMA in 1947. The elmwood Reclining Figure, 1939, has been part of a Moore retrospective at Tate Modern this summer and will travel to Toronto and some US cities, with other works currently in the Tate exhibition. Provenance information issued by the Tate, indicates: Gordon Onslow Ford purchased it from Moore in 1941; The Detroit Institute of Arts, Detroit, current owner, purchased it from the Marlborough-Gerson Gallery, New York, 1965. So there is a gap in knowledge, but since Gordon Onslow Ford [ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Onslow_Ford ], was in New York in 1941, it is likely that the piece was too.I agree with maruteru that this is probably Moore's Reclining Figure, 1939.

On December 15, 1913, Diry, a middleweight, was knocked out by George Ashe, in the third round of a contest at the National Sporting Club, in Brooklyn, New York. Diry had come to America from Ireland, where his name was spelled (and pronounced) "Deery." This was his second loss in a row, and he went on to lose three more times by knockouts early in 1914, before hanging up his gloves for good. Diry's boxing record: boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=73885&cat=boxer New York Times story, December 16, 1913: (NYT says he was a German. NYT also says he had won several earlier fights, but the record contradicts that statement.) query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E... Looks like this guy, appointed Interstate Commerce Commissioner by Pres. Wilson in 1914. Interesting misspelling... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Clay_Hall

Woodrow Wilson appointed Henry Clay Hall to the ICC (to fill a vacancy) on January 30, 1914. A New York native, Hall at that time was President of the Bar Association of Colorado. New York Times story, January 31, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9407E0DA1730E7... A New York Times story on February 6 reported that confirmation of Hall's appointment had been held up in a U. S. Senate committee: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B06E4DE113FE6... The photo above is dated February 17, 1914: that's probably when Hall's appointment was confirmed by the Senate. The Bain Agency then circulated the photo to its subscribers.

Princess Victoria Melita of Edinburgh (25 November 1876 – 2 March 1936), was a daughter of Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh and a granddaughter of Queen Victoria as well as of Tsar Alexander II of Russia. In 1894 she married her paternal first cousin Ernest Louis, Grand Duke of Hesse. Their marriage was a failure and ended in divorce in 1901. Victoria scandalized the royal families of Europe when she married her maternal first cousin Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich in 1905. Family opposition was so great that the couple was initially banished from Russia. In 1909 they were allowed to return. After the fall of the Russian monarchy in 1917, they were forced to live in exile. In 1926 Kirill self proclaimed emperor in exile and Victoria Melita supported her husband claims. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Victoria_Melita_of_Saxe-Co...

Information from the Division of Manuscripts, Cornell University Library:

BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE 

Elizabeth Greene Gardiner was a social worker and professor. She served as a nurse's aide with the Italian Red Cross in Imola, Italy (1915-1916) and with the British Expeditionary Force in France (1917-1919). She was involved in medical social work on Ellis Island (1919-1922) and at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital (1926-1928). From 1928 to 1938 she was assistant professor at the University of Minnesota; during 1931 she served as exchange lecturer at the University of Liverpool, England. She also served as a consultant for the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness (1939-1942), an analyst of convalescent homes for the Committee on Convalescent Care Practice, New York City (1942-1943), and as a Welfare Officer for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in Egypt, Italy and Germany (1944-1946); also intermittently for the Citizen's Committee on Displaced Persons, New York City, the American Committee for Emigre Scholars, Writers and Artists, New York City, and the Travelers Aid Society, Nashville, Tennessee. Gardiner received her academic training at Simmons College School of Social Work, Columbia University, and the University of Chicago. She was involved in numerous professional organizations, and visited many social, health, and educational agencies in Europe and Asia.

Frank A. Bicknell (1866-1943) was an American painter: www.questroyalfineart.com/2077/ogunquit-maine.html

Bicknell was a performer in the New York Beaux Arts Society's pageant of the history of Venice, presented at the Hotel Astor on February 20, 1914. New York Times story, February 21, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D03E0DF163AE6... Frank Bicknell and seven other painters from the summer artists' colony in Old Lyme, Connecticut, in 1914 founded the Lyme Art Association, and erected a gallery adjacent to the Agnes Richardson mansion to showcase their work. www.lymeartassociation.org/history.php From a description of a painting of Bicknell's in an exhibition: Frank A. Bicknell (1866-1943) "Ogunquit, Maine" Oil on artist's board Gift of Mr. Charles Tyler 1973.18 "Bicknell's small painting renders the sun-drenched coast of Maine with startling freshness. Working on the spot with a palette knife, the artist applied paint directly to the board to construct the rock's craggy surface. He used the color of the bare support itself to suggest the cliff's sharp crevices. "Bicknell, who never married and was likely gay, regarded Miss Florence [Richardson] and the members of the Lyme Art Colony as "the family." He and other Lyme artists sometimes fled Connecticut's late summer humidity to sketch and fish in Maine. In addition to painting in Ogunquit, a small fishing village on Maine's south coast, Bicknell spent time with Lyme artists Walter Griffin, Arthur Heming, and Charles Ebert at Monhegan Island. Bicknell maintained a life-long connection to Lyme through the home left to him as a bequest by the artist Lewis Cohen, a fellow Griswold House boarder."

William Starling Burgess (1878-1947) was a naval architect and aviation pioneer: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Starling_Burgess He married five times; but this wife would likely be artist Rosamund Tudor Burgess (1878-1949), mother of their three children born 1905, 1907, and 1915. Their older son Edward died at age 5 in 1910, by falling off a boat. Their daughter Starling Burgess used the name Tasha Tudor and became an illustrator.

Tasha Tudor (1915-2008) was famous -- a talented illustrator, whose old-timey scenes decorated calendars, greeting cards, and children's books. When she died at age 92, she left an estate worth about two million dollars. A Tasha Tudor images sampler: www.google.com/images?q=tasha+tudor&rls=com.microsoft... Wikipedia on Tasha Tudor: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tasha_Tudor

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH MUTUAL FILM CO.:
"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

A hotel-room scandal featuring Senator Gore!  In February 1914, Minnie Bond accused Senator Thomas Gore of Oklahoma of attempting to assault her in a Washington hotel.  Her husband was hoping for a political appointment from Senator Gore; in disappointment about not getting that appointment, the Bonds may have concocted this story, in hopes of blackmailing the senator.

Albrecht Luitpold Ferdinand Michael, Duke of Bavaria, of Franconia and in Swabia, Count Palatine of the Rhine ( 3 May 1905 – 8 July 1996), was the son of Rupprecht, Crown Prince of Bavaria and his first wife, Duchess Marie Gabrielle in Bavaria. He was the one surviving child from that marriage. His paternal grandfather was Ludwig III of Bavaria, the last King of Bavaria who was deposed in 1918. His family, the House of Wittelsbach, were opposed to the regime of Nazi Germany and in 1940 Albrecht took his family to his estate at Sárvár, Vas, Hungary. In October 1944, when Germany occupied Hungary, the Wittelsbachs were arrested and imprisoned in the Sachsenhausen concentration camp at Oranienburg, Brandenburg. In April 1945 they were moved to the Dachau concentration camp, where they were liberated by the United States Army. Albrecht became Head of the Royal Family of Bavaria with the death of his father on 2 August 1955. From that date he was regarded by Jacobites as the rightful King of England, Scotland, Ireland and France. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albrecht,_Duke_of_Bavaria

In the late 1940s there was a revival of interest in the early 20th century New Orleans jazz music style. This advertising with a live band on a horse drawn bandwagon is no doubt a reference to it. The New Orleans bandwagons of 30- 50 years earlier would never have had a piano on them, just portable instruments. However since the band leader here was great jazz pianist Art Hodes, apparently an exception was made. Must have been some work getting the piano into the wagon.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunk_Johnson After first recording in New Orleans, Bunk and his New Orleans band got positive attention and made some more fine recordings in New York City. However Bunk was unreliable, sometimes showing up drunk or not at all. After returning to New Orleans, his sidemen George Lewis and Jim Robinson blamed Bunk's lack of professionalism for spoiling their chance to make it into the "big time" up north. After Bunk's death they got another chance, and the band under leadership of clarinetist George Lewis became a very successful jazz group in the 1950s. Bunk is shown with Maude Balque, generally known as Maude Johnson, although they were not actually legally married until 1949, less than 6 months before Bunk's death.

Trumpeter Bunk Johnson at left; guitarist/composer/blues singer Leadbelly at right. Clarinetist George Lewis seen sitting at bottom left; string bass player Alcide "Slow Drag" Pavageau in background behind Leadbelly's microphone.  This is the band of New Orleans musicians assembled by Bunk and Bill Russell in New Orleans when Bunk came out of retirement and which he later took up to New York City, with Leadbelly added.

The Library of Congress is currently posting photos from the Bain News Agency's 1914 photostream. The 1920 date on the (glass) negative represents a later re-use of the image by Bain.

What's the story behind this photo? Were the guns confiscated from criminals? Were they no longer needed as evidence? Why not melt them down as scrap metal? The rifle barrels look like they've been deliberately bent.

Some police agencies nowadays do send the confiscated guns to be melted down for scrap -- often on an annual basis. Usually the agency collecting the guns from various jurisdictions is a State Police force. The guns have been used in crimes, or seized during domestic quarrels, or voluntarily surrendered by members of the public. The order to destroy them comes from a judge, often at the end of a criminal trial. Sometimes, if a weapon is unusual, a police agency will ask the judge for permission to keep the weapon for training purposes, or for use by a SWAT team. In Connecticut, until 1992, confiscated guns were not scrapped, but sold to the public at auction.

Another Bain/LOC photo shows a high-ranking police officer throwing these guns into the sea:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4818636438/in/photostream/]

Yet another Bain/LOC photo of the forfeited guns aboard ship:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4909923045/in/photostream/]

In 1913, Ralph De Palma won the Vanderbilt Cup Race on Long Island, driving a Mercedes on a set of Braender tires, which lasted the entire 500 miles without a tire change. So, is this DePalma? Might be -- and maybe he was planning to repeat his feat now, in 1914?

Braender Bulldog tires were manufactured by a company in East Rutherford, New Jersey, that had been founded in 1912 by Philip Braender, a German immigrant. (When Braender died in 1916, he left a million bucks to his wife and children. The tire company continued on into the 1920s.)

technogeo points out that this photo was taken by an Indianapolis studio -- so, presumably in Indianapolis. De Palma won the Indy 500 race in 1915 (and nearly won in 1912) driving a Mercedes racer. He won other races elsewhere as well, in Mercedes.

His Wikipedia bio includes a photo of him with his riding mechanic, Tom Alley, in his 1912 Indy car. It probably was this one -- which is now an exhibit in the Indy hall of fame museum.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_De_Palma en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Braender

Former President Theodore Roosevelt, at age 55, defeated in his 1912 attempt at election for a third term as the candidate of the Progressive ("Bull Moose") Party, in 1913 sailed for Brazil to embark on his life's last great adventure, exploring the uncharted rain forest via the River of Doubt. Marked by poor planning, inadequate equipment, and a surfeit of bad luck, the expedition was harrowing, to put it mildly, and TR nearly died (as in fact another in the party did) -- but ultimately in 1914 he and his son, Kermit, and others on the trek returned to the embrace of civilization. (And the River of Doubt now bears the name Rio Roosevelt.) Roosevelt lived to write a book about his ordeal, "Through the Brazilian Wilderness." The story has recently been updated and retold in a gripping bestseller (2005) by Candice Millard -- "The River of Doubt; Theodore Roosevelt's Darkest Journey," a book that comes highly recommended by its many readers, myself included.

TR's own memoir of the ordeal is available to readers online, via Google Books.

Rheta Childe Dorr (1868-1948): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rheta_Childe_Dorr
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmeline_Pankhurst

Emmeline Pankhurst, the British Suffragette leader, sailed to New York from England in October, 1913. It was her third visit to the USA, where she had scheduled a busy fundraising lecture tour. Her companion on the voyage was Rheta Childe Dorr; the ladies filled time during the seven days at sea compiling Pankhurst's autobiography (Dorr in the role of stenographer, Pankhurst dictating) -- a book published in 1914 (and now available to readers online, via Google Books). But back home, Pankhurst was in trouble with the law, and U. S. immigration authorities, anticipating her arrival, used that as a pretext to deny her entry to the States -- indeed, they held an emergency hearing, declared her undesirable, and decided to send her back to England immediately -- meanwhile holding her and Ms. Dorr in comfortable quarters at Ellis Island. Newspaper publicity, and protests by American suffragists -- including Pankhurst's would-be hostess, Mrs. O. H. P. Belmont, one of the richest women in America -- embarrassed the government, and made it necessary for President Woodrow Wilson personally to intervene to have Mrs. Pankhurst released. The controversy brought a publicity windfall, greatly enhancing donations to the suffragist cause. New York Times story on Wilson's intervention, October 20, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9505E... Another 1913 Bain/LOC photo of Mrs. Pankhurst, the canny publicity monger: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4818632528/in/photostream/] FLASHBACK: On November 27, 1911, during an earlier visit to New York City, Emmeline Pankhurst attempted to convert a hostile crowd of young male yahoos in Wall Street, by lecturing from the back seat of an open automobile. [They probably found her British accent amusing.] Her foray into the financial jungle was not successful; the lads drowned her out and shouted her down: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163792086/]
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmeline_Pankhurst

Emmeline Pankhurst, the British Suffragette leader, sailed from her home in England to New York, in October, 1913. It was her third visit to the USA, where she had scheduled a busy fundraising lecture tour. Her companion on the voyage was Rheta Childe Dorr; the ladies filled time during seven days at sea compiling Pankhurst's autobiography (Dorr in the role of stenographer, Mrs. Pankhurst dictating) -- a book published in 1914 (and now available to readers online, via Google Books). But back home, Pankhurst was in trouble with the law, and U. S. immigration authorities, anticipating her arrival, used her legal troubles as a pretext to accuse her of "moral turpitude," denying her entry to the States -- indeed, they held an emergency hearing and decided to send her back to England immediately. Meanwhile she and Ms. Dorr were held in comfortable quarters at Ellis Island. The resultant newspaper publicity, and protests by American suffragists -- including Pankhurst's would-be hostess, Mrs. Oliver Hazzard Perry Belmont, one of the richest women in America -- embarrassed the government, and made it necessary for President Woodrow Wilson personally to intervene to have Mrs. Pankhurst released. The controversy brought a publicity windfall, greatly enhancing donations to the suffragist cause. New York Times story, October 20, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9505E... Here is another Bain/LOC photo from October, 1913 -- taken while Pankhurst and Dorr were being held at Ellis Island, pending deportation: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4818632678/in/photostream/]

Francis B. Sayre (1885-1972): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Bowes_Sayre

President Woodrow Wilson's daughter, Jessie Woodrow Wilson, married Francis Bowes Sayre in a White House ceremony, on November 25, 1913. On December 1, 1913, the bridal couple embarked on a honeymoon voyage to Europe, aboard the North German Lloyd vessel, "Vulcan," with Captain Ludwig Franck.

Prince Henry of Prussia (born Albert Wilhelm Heinrich, 14 August 1862 – 20 April 1929) was a younger brother of German Emperor William II and a Prince of Prussia. A career naval officer, he held various commands in the Imperial German Navy and eventually rose to the rank of Grand Admiral. Born in Berlin, Prince Henry of Prussia was the third of eight children born to Crown Prince Frederick (later Emperor Frederick III), and Victoria, Princess Royal of the United Kingdom (later Empress Victoria and in widowhood Empress Frederick), a daughter of the British Queen Victoria. Henry was three years younger than his brother, the future Emperor William II (born 27 January 1859). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Henry_of_Prussia_(1862-1929)

Guests at a New York City costume party, January, 1914. In 1914, Rea Irvin already had a reputation as a New York bon vivant. A comic artist for Red Book magazine, in that year he illustrated numerous Red Book stories written by the humorist Ellis Parker Butler (who is now best remembered for his story, "Pigs Is Pigs.) Before WWI, Irvin also contributed a steady stream of illustrations to the old "Life" magazine, a humor weekly. Irvin in 1925 became the first art editor of a new magazine, "The New Yorker," for which he designed the first cover, a portrait of Eustace Tilley, the supercilious Regency fop who became the magazine's symbol. Tilley's pose is parodied here: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/idogcow/4289390151/] Rea Irvin's Wikipedia bio: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rea_Irvin

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM CO.:
"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

Eleftherios Venizelos (Wikipedia), Prime Minister of Greece 1910-1915.

Venizelos, a liberal reformer, was Prime Minister of Greece from 1910 to 1920, and from 1928 to 1932. A champion of embattled Serbia during World War I, he sided with the Entente powers against the Alliance powers that included Germany and Austria, which had attacked Serbia. In opposing Germany's war aims, Venizelos clashed with the Greek king, Constantine, a German supporter, whose wife was German. The rift between the head of state and the head of government produced a schism at the top of the Greek government.
"Venizelos, Maker of Modern Greece," lengthy review of a newly-published biography of Venizelos -- New York Times, October 30, 1921: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9505E...

Captain McClintock was appointed First Deputy Police Commissioner of New York City on February 1, 1914. A New York Times story (December 8, 1914) hinted that his resignation only ten months later was motivated by a desire to accept a police post in the new (and USA-administered) Panama Canal Zone: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9B00E...

Actress Estelle Stead?  Her father William T Stead was a writer interested in paranormal subjects, who died on the Titanic.  Estelle Stead sought contact with her father's spirit for many years after that, and wrote about her experiences in seances and with mediums.  There's a spirit photograph of Estelle Stead that looks like this woman only older.

Estelle published a 345-page biography of her father in 1913, a year after he went down with the Titanic. The book placed heavy emphasis on his interest in Spiritualism, including phenomena like spirit photographs -- an interest that she shared. Like her father, Estelle Wilson Stead was English (lived near Cambridge, England), but also had strong U. S. ties, and her book was published in New York as well as in London. The Bain News Agency probably circulated this photograph to its subscribers when the book came out. The work may now be read online, digitized by Google Books: books.google.com/books?id=zmioaaaayaaj&pg=pa292&d...
Note to LOC -- the middle initial "H" on Bain's photo caption appears to be incorrect.

A Mrs. Jane Brown was arrested at Gimbels in January 1914, according to the New York Times.  She was accused of trying to use a counterfeit $50 bill.  She told officers that she was born in San Francisco to English parents, and that she'd been in New York about nine months--but she also gave a fake address when asked.

FRAULEIN NOW PROFESSOR.; Rachel Hirsch the First Woman Physician to Gain That Title. Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES. November 16, 1913, Sunday Berlin, Nov. 15 — Unusual honors have been won by Fräulein Rachel Hirsch, who is the first woman physician in Germany to acquire the title of Professor. Fräulein Hirsch, for the past five years, has been the chief assistant of Prof. Kraus, and has conducted a polyclinic for both men and women patients of the university medical clinic of the Berlin Charity Hospital. Fräulein Prof. Dr. Hirsch, which will henceforth be her full title, has not only been active in hospital service but has also done superior research work in the fever and bacteriological fields, also in connection with diabetes and kindred diseases.
"Fräulein Prof. Dr. Hirsch" the Germans always love those long titles.

I added his to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain_John_McClintock He was the son of Emory McClintock of of the Mutual Life Insurance Company. He attended Berkeley School and later Columbia University and the New York University School of Law. His United States Army service began in the Spanish American War. Frank Swett Black appointed him a major in the 203rd New York Volunteers. He was appointed by Douglas Imrie McKay as a First Deputy Police Commissioner of New York City on February 1, 1914. He resigned on December 15, 1914 in the aftermath of the killing of Barnet Baff.

On February 4, 1914 (the date on this photo) former Congressman Lucius Littauer, a wealthy glove manufacturer from Gloversville, New York, was in court, pleading guilty to a charge of smuggling. He and his brother (and partner-in-crime) paid fines, but their prison sentences were suspended. Several New York officials declared Littauer eligible to continue serving as a member of the New York State Board of Regents (Department of Education), but at the next meeting of the Regents, he resigned that position. Littauer and his brother had smuggled a valuable tiara into the country, without paying customs duty. "Littauers Enter Pleas of Guilty" New York Times story, February 4, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E06EEDA1730E7... "Littauers Pay Fine, But Escape Prison" New York Times story, February 5, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B02E5D71F3BE6... The District Attorney thought that conviction meant that the Littauer brothers had surrendered rights of citizenship. New York Times story, February 6, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9501E4DE113FE6... "Littauer Still A Regent" New York Times story, February 12, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9F05E... "Littauer Out As Regent" A follow-up story, NYT, February 27, 1914, reports Littauer's resignation from the New York Board of Regents: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B01E6DE163AE6...

"Miskinoff" is a misspelling of "Mishkinoff." [Misspelling is Bain's fault this time, not LOC's.] Prince Alex Mishkinoff was an indigent shirttail member of the Russian nobility, who married California railroad heiress Aimee for her wealth. He was her fourth husband. Then he was accused of statutory rape, having had sexual relations with her 15-year-old daughter by a previous marriage. Aimee divorced him. (Then she married one more time.) A lot of juicy details spilled out in court. New York Times story, February 14, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C02E6D8153AE6... Guaymas is a city and municipality located in the southwest part of the state of Sonora in northwestern Mexico. The city is located 117 km south of the state capital of Hermosillo, and 242 miles from the U.S. border, and is the principal port for the state.

During the Mexican Revolution, the first aerial bombardment of a naval target in the world occurred just off the coast of Guaymas. In 1913, five military ships belonging to Federal forces appeared in the bay. General Alvaro Obregon of the rebel army ordered the bombing of these ships using the aircraft named “Sonora.”

Information about the S.S. Deutschland that was renamed the Viktoria Luise from 1910-1921.

the web being what it is, there is some slightly contradictory information floating around. Wikipedia seems to imply that as soon as she was converted to a cruise ship, she was painted all white (as seen here on a company postcard , oceanlinerpostcards.blogspot.com/2007_06_01_archive.html .) however, clearly the name came before the paint job. Since the postcard seems to be from 1911, and the ship was renamed and re-purposed in 1910, this is probably her initial voyage into New York under her new name, because of her dressed out flags. her initial claim to fame: Launched in 1900, she won the Blue Riband from the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse of the North German Lloyd line, crossing the Atlantic Ocean in just a little over five days.

Some more clues from the NY Times Archive OLD DEUTSCHLAND IN PORT.; She's the Victoria Luise Now and the Largest Cruising Steamer Afloat. RIVAL WORLD CRUISES.; Speedy, Deutschland Is Being Rebuilt for Leisurely Voyaging.

Wikipedia seems to imply that as soon as she was converted to a cruise ship, she was painted all white (as seen here on a company postcard, oceanlinerpostcards.blogspot.com/2007_06_01_archive.html .) however, clearly the name came before the paint job. Since the postcard seems to be from 1911, and the ship was renamed and re-purposed in 1910, this is probably her initial voyage into New York under her new name, because of her dressed out flags. her initial claim to fame: Launched in 1900, she won the Blue Riband from the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse of the North German Lloyd line, crossing the Atlantic Ocean in just a little over five days.

The Victoria Luise stopped in San Juan Harbor in Puerto Rico, during her February, 1914, West Indies cruise: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/fredandrebecca/4316383350/] Date on photo is evidence that the ship was not white in 1914: www.flickr.com/photos/fredandrebecca/4316383350/ The postcard view on Wikipedia is not a photograph, but a painting. Perhaps it was issued before the revamp job on the Deutschland, showing it white as then planned, but not as it actually got painted. A sailor was killed and five others were injured in an accident aboard the Victoria Luise while the ship was still in Hoboken harbor on January 9, 1914, before sarting its West Indies cruise. New York Times story, January 10, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9801E0DD1730E7...

East Aurora, New York, is in the Buffalo area. A hundred years ago, it was famous as the home of the Roycrofters, an artisans community founded by Elbert Hubbard, an exponent of the Arts and Crafts movement. Some of the Roycroft buildings are undergoing restoration now. The Roycroft colony had its own baseball team, which used the Roycroft logo on its uniforms. Perhaps they played the East Aurora team from time to time.

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM CO.:
"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

interesting woman, from Wiki: her marriage was unhappy and childless. (Years after the fact, it was mooted that Aribert was homosexual and had been caught in bed with a servant, either by Marie Louise or his father.) In December 1900, her father-in-law used his prerogative as reigning Duke of Anhalt to annul the marriage. Princess Marie Louise, on an official visit to Canada at the time, immediately returned to Britain. According to her memoirs, she regarded her marriage vows as binding, so she never remarried. Her memoirs do, however, indicate rage over her marital experience and an obvious dislike of her former husband en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Marie_Louise_of_Schleswig-...

She happened to be in the news at this time because on January 18, 1914, she arrived with a sightseeing party of British nobility in Colon, Panama -- where, as guests of the British minister there, they intended to do some sightseeing on the new Panama Canal before continuing on to Jamaica. New York Times story, January 19, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9A06E...
Baseball executive John Arnold Heydler (1869-1956): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Heydler

In 1914, Heydler was President of Baseball's National League. He returned to the league headquarters in New York City in January, after attending the joint schedule meeting in French Lick Springs, Indiana, and a recent conference with the Players' Fraternity at Cincinnati. In a New York Times story, Heydler spelled out some of the decisions that had been made at the two meetings. New York Times, January 11, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A0DE0DF1E39E6...

On February 1, 1914, Captain John McClintock was appointed First Deputy Police Commissioner of New York City. He resigned ten months later; a New York Times story on December 8, 1914, hinted that the resignation had been inspired by a desire to accept a police post in the newly-created (and USA-administered) Panama Canal Zone. (McClintock had formerly held a customs post in Panama.): query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9B00E... Other Bain/LOC portraits of Capt. H. M. Waite was an MIT graduate, a city engineer in Cincinnati, and City Manager of Dayton OH, elected in December 1913.  In 1918, he joined to war effort, serving in France as a transportation engineer, and in Trier Germany in charge of public works after the armistice.

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH MUTUAL FILM CO.:
"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

Roy Repp in his bucking Buick ("Maude, the Motor Mule") circa 1915 in New York

Other Bain/LOC photos of Roy Repp and his Bucking Buick:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4786746669/in/photostream/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4786746461/in/photostream/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4787378228/in/photostream/]

Sliding weights, concealed beneath the trunk, enabled Repp to tip the vehicle forward or back:

"[1913 or 1914] photo by Bain News Service of . . . stunt driver Roy Repp and his “bucking” Buick automobile performing for onlookers in New York. Repp and his unusual trick car, dubbed “Maude the Motor Mule”, often performed at race meets – he astonished spectators by making his car run on its “hind legs”, spinning it around, bucking it into the air and generally making the car behave like a circus horse or mule. The Buick had a heavy weight hung over the rear end of the vehicle, concealed beneath a housing, and had individual brakes on each rear wheel. The driver controlled the position of the weight with a lever – deliberately overbalancing the car by moving the weight and making the vehicle buck into the air. Applying one of the independent brakes and locking one of the wheels then allowed the car to spin around on that wheel. The exhibition was often performed in time to music from an accompanying band which played a waltz."

A three-paragraph item about Roy Repp and his Buick appeared, with a photograph, in Popular Science Monthly, volume 87 (December 1915). books.google.com/books?id=6s3uaaaamaaj&pg=pa782&l... repp&f=false A follow-up item appeared in the January, 1916 issue, (volume 88), on page 87. This time, Repp and his car appeared on the magazine's cover, but alas, the cover has not been included in the bound volume digitized for Google Books: books.google.com/books?id=ess4aaaaiaaj&pg=pa87&lp...

Although in some accounts he was erroneously described as a native of Australia, Leroy (or Lee Roy) Repp in fact was born in Mansfield, Ohio, on May 12, 1882. He died at 52, on January 4, 1934, a bit over two months after he was struck by a wing nut that flew off a speeding race car during time trials at a meet in Shreveport, Louisiana, on October 29, 1933. Repp had been officiating at the meet: www.motorsportmemorial.org/focus.php?db=ct&n=8414

American Expeditionary Force Prevost Marshal General John C. Groome. He is wearing a collar pin for the First Troop Philadelphia City Cavalry. This may be a recycled image when he was younger and in the Spanish American War. I started a biography for him in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_C._Groome_(Pennsylvania) He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on March 20, 1862, one of six children, of Samuel William Groome and Nancy Andrew Connelly. He was privately tutored and graduated from the Protestant Episcopal Academy in 1878. He became a member of the First Troop Philadelphia City Cavalry in 1882 and was promoted to Corporal in 1887, then Sergeant in 1889. He was lastly appointed as Captain in 1896, and was re-elected to that position again in 1901. He was active in the Homestead Strike in 1892 and the Coal Strike of 1902 in 1902. In 1905 he became the first commissioner of the Pennsylvania State Police. He retired from the Pennsylvania State Police on February 28, 1920 and died August 31, 1939 at the age of 68

Neapolitans have never eaten pasta with their hands out of choice. I'd guess that this scene was set up by the American photographer to show the folks back home how strange/primitive these Italians were. I'm half Italian and if this wasn't an historical document I'd find it wholly offensive.

Alan Denney, I hope you will understand Italian well, because my english is too bad :o) The picture could be offensive, but... do you remember the famous italian comedian-actors Toto e Peppino ?? Si lo so, noi come lo spero anche voi negli USA non abbiamo mai mangiato con le mani gli spaghetti, ma qualcuno forse, per povertà, l'avrà fatto. Questa immagine, come le commedie di Toto e Peppino, sono delle caricature comiche, una rappresentazione folkloristica di un modo di vivere italiano. Sarebbe infatti necessario, e questo potresti scriverlo meglio tu, dire che sono appunto immagini che rappresentano vizi e abitudini in modo grottesco e scherzoso, ma non sono la rappresentazione della vita reale.

Grazie Wozz (- l'atra meta e inglese e abito a Londra). 
Wozz points out that that this image is in the same genre as the comic carictures of Neapolitan entertainers like Toto and Peppino and that as such they aren't a faithful representation of real life. I agree but it's one thing for an Italian audience to consume such images and quite another for them to be presented in a US publication for a non-Italian audience which would not have been able to make such a nuanced reading as Wozz proposes.My point is that we are more likely to have a positive view of foreigners if  ourperception of them is not based on comic caricatures. These days we're floooded with images of people from all over the world but when this image was disseminated it may well have been the only picture many people had seen of Italians.
Alan, you're right.
A century ago, common usage in the USA was to call all pasta "macaroni".

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/alandenney/] You're looking at an image from the late 19th century, when it was still absolutely common to attach human zoos to World's Fairs to show the visitors how "primitive tribes" behaved in their habitat, including the 1893 Columbian Exposition in Chicago with its famed Midway Plaisance. Also, the print originates in Switzerland  – Photoglob Zürich, the original publisher, routinely purchased black & white photos  from local photographers in bulk to turn into color photochroms, so chances are this is is how a Neapolitan photographer saw his hometown. The Detroit Publishing Co. was simply the North American licensee. PZ captioned most of its prints in the local language to add some local flair, but as you can see from the many comments in this set, they often enough got it wrong...
Bellissimo

Joining the conversation a few years later, I found an entry in the scholarly Encyclopedia of Pasta by Oretta Zanini De Vita, which says that poor workers eating pasta with cheese by hand was a common sight in Naples during and after the 18th century, when pasta was finally cheap enough for the poor to eat. According to de Vita: "Grand Tour travelers to Naples watched with amusement the daily meal of the so-called lazzari, at the street corners, who with a deft movement of the fingers, slid maccheroni dressed with cheese into their mouths." The maccheroni in use was not the macaroni of America, but was similar to bucatini, long, straight, and with a hole in the middle. books.google.com/books?id=D5nXAbSifIgC&lpg=PA6&ot... LOC: One improvement that can be made in your online presentation of the Photochroms is to include the caption on the print itself in your Notes. Instead, it looks like you have in all cases used an identification that comes from the American publisher's catalog. In some cases, like this one, the English translation is wrong and/or misleading. Trialanderrors, above, touches on this too. Also, researchers who have the print and want to use the caption to search online cannot reach it in your collection. I think you should add the captions, though I'm sure that is not a simple project.

From this site. www.jewishitaly.org/detail.asp?ID=74 Apparently it is still there. The heart of the community is an imposing 1880 synagogue, with mosque-like turrets and three different worship spaces. The top level houses festival celebrations, the sunken sanctuary below is home to the weekly Shabbat services and the smallest space displays an ark from the original ghetto synagogue, its ornate decorations repainted in black and gold, to honor King Carlo Alberto who in 1848, abolished the ghetto, only to die the following year. It’s a typical post-emancipation synagogue grand, monumental, because after years of ghetto life, Jewish people wanted to show their presence here. And here is another site with a good history of the Jewish community in Turin. www.smithgcb.demon.co.uk/pied_hadassah.htm

Ciao volevo segnalarti questo concorso fotografico che si svolge qui su Flickr è GRATUITO ed il PRIMO PREMIO è un iPad!! Applicazione della pietra in architettura Il trimestrale F Stone Magazine lancia il suo primo concorso internazionale di fotografia. I temi a cui sono chiamati a ispirarsi i partecipanti al concorso sono Classic e Green. Classic, architettura classica: Uno scatto per sorprendere la pietra impiegata nel modo più tradizionale nell'architettura, dal classico al moderno Green, architettura bio: Una foto che colga l'utilizzo del materiale lapideo in un contesto di ecosostenibilità, nell'ottica quindi del rispetto dell'ambiente, dell'efficienza energetica e dell'impiego di materiali naturali: un punto di osservazione pensato con la logica della biocompatibilità. La partecipazione è GRATUITA, il PRIMO CLASSIFICATO riceverà un iPad con Wi-Fi 16 GB, il secondo classificato una Canon Power Shot S90. Il concorso si svolge esclusivamente on line, ed è riservato ai maggiori di 18 anni. I partecipanti sono chiamati a inviare le opere fotografiche entro il 10 maggio 2011. per maggiori informazioni www.furrer.it/it/magazine/if-photo-award.asp

O. B. Willmarth, President of Colorado Carnotite Company, a radium mining concern. We work now under sufficient difficulty without being restricted to an insignificant American market." (16 January 1914, NY Times)

PANCHO VILLA'S ARRANGEMENT WITH THE MUTUAL FILM COMPANY:

"In January 1914, Pancho Villa became Hollywood's first Mexican superstar when he signed an exclusive contract with the Mutual Film Corporation. In return for $25,000, he agreed to keep other film companies from his battlefield, to fight in daylight whenever possible, and to reconstruct battles if the footage needed reshooting. 

"Now the subject of an HBO film starring Antonio Banderas (And Starring Pancho Villa as Himself), Villa is one of the main protagonists in Margarita de Orellana's vivid account of the American movie industry's fascination with the events of the Mexican Revolution. 

"Through memoir accounts, newspaper reports, and analysis of the films themselves, "Filming Pancho" reveals much about how Mexico was constructed in the American imagination and how the film images reinforced and justified American expansionism and racial and social prejudices."

--From a description, on Amazon, of a documentary movie of Hollywood's treatment of the Mexican Revolution. (The DVD is available for purchase from various Amazon vendors.)

Esta foto pudiera corresponder al 25 de noviembre de 1913  (por la secuencia 2961-2), después de la Batalla de Tierra Blanca.  Se aprecia el botín de guerra en el fondo hay otras fotos del mismo acto, en el mismo sitio, que hacen juego con ésta. El día 3 de enero de 1914 Villa firmó su contrato con la Mutual para que esta compañía filmara sus batallas.
La Batalla de Ojinaga se llevó a cabo el dia 10 de enero.  En todo caso la foto correspondería a esta fecha. Y el que lo acompaña no es un director holiwoodense, se trata del general Pánfilo Natera
Dr. Roberto Duarte

Wystan pro has set Gen Rodríguez's picture 14th from top (2nd from below)
Call nr.  LC-B2-3046-9, to differentiate from Pánfilo Natera.

Maybe you wonder what Panfilo Natera has to do in this picture taken in the northern border of the State of Chihuahua, being a revolutionary general that  used to fight in the central State of Zacatecas?
Well, by December 20 Villa summoned main generals in Chihuahua to organize the strategy to attack Ojinaga.  Natera was also present (because he was trying to confer Carranza in Sonora, but American authorities declined to let him pass through El Paso).  Villa proposed Toribio Ortega, or as a courtesy, Pánfilo Natera to take command of the army.  The generals chose Natera.  The column departed from Chihuahua on December 22, 1913.  On January 2, 1914 villistas were on sight to Ojinaga, on January 4ht town was attacked without success.  Then Villa took command of the army.  His plan was a nocturnal raid: Rosalío Hernandes by the south; Maclovio Herrera and Trinidad Rodríguez  by east; by the West Toribio Ortega. On January 11th at sunset, the raids went simultaneously.   The federals (huertistas), leaving fire arms, crossed Rio Bravo and surrendered to American authorities. Villa and his revolutionary army stayed in Ojinaga three or four days, then they returned to Chihuahua.  (Pedro Salmerón, La División Del Norte).  So this picture (and 4th, 5th above [Mutual]) were taken among those days.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

According to Salmerón, the date scratched it rather be 1/14/14 (January 14, 1914), after Ojinaga´s take.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

293 Bowery @ Houston, looking north along the short block to E. 1st Street. There's some kind of garden and a glassed-in apartment building called the Avalon there now (Google Street View). A little more about the buildings on the right: "Between 1884 and 1932, the Bowery YMCA, housed for a time at Wesley Hall (291-293 Bowery), also provided mission-style services and housing. Today the building houses a Tibetan Buddhist meditation and teaching center. McGurk’s Suicide Hall at 295 Bowery also became a rescue mission for a time during the early 20th century." www.placeinhistory.org/projects/bowery/?page=10 50 years earlier (1863), the same spot was the location of a huge hotel fire covered in the NY Times. The building next door (295 Bowery) was a tobacco warehouse heavily damaged by water during the fighting of the fire.
I like the el tracks in the upper left-hand corner. I'll use this shot in a lesson for my 8th graders in our New York City Unit.

Yes, the elevated tracks you can see in this pic were narrow because they were one-way -- the uptown el ran on one side of the street above one sidewalk and the downtown el on the other side of the street above the other sidewalk. Bowery is a wide street and had several parallel streetcar lines on the street in between the two el trestles, as seen here. The Bowery el was built in 1878 and torn down in 1955. McGuirk's Suicide Hall, at the location of the "RESTAURANT" seen in this pic, was a notorious theater/saloon sort of establishment that supposedly acquired its nickname because so many young women committed suicide there. Some of these buildings actually lasted until 2005 when they were torn down for the Avalon. Next block up is where CBGB's used to be.
it merited a small article in Time Magazine in 1926 for making men get up and out at 5 AM! www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,728797,00.html as noted on the sign, doors opened at 7pm.

The Hadley Hall was originally the "Volksgarten."  Per nysonglines.com : 

 "In the 19th Century, a gathering place for the German-American community that once dominated this neighborhood. Later Wesley Hall, a notable Bowery mission, which was renamed Hadley Hall after Samuel Hadley, the Civil War vet who ran the mission for many years. A venue for labor meetings. For the past 40 years it has housed Stanton Trading, a restaurant supply company. It too was demolished in 2005--respresenting a failure of the Landmark Commission to preserve New York's historic buildings. "

Al Jennings (1863-1961) was a Virginia-born Oklahoma lawyer who was also a train robber and a silent-film star. He died in Tarzana CA, age 98. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Jennings See his mugshot here: www.texashillcountry.com/Stories/AlJennings.htm

David Franklin Houston (1866-1940) was Chancellor of Washington University in St. Louis (1908-1913), and US Secretary of Agriculture (1913-1920), then briefly was the US Secretary of the Treasury after that: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_F._Houston

The unidentified man at the left. looking like an undertaker, is William Gibbs McAdoo, Secretary of the Treasury in the administration of President Woodrow Wilson. Secretaries McAdoo and Houston formed a two-man committee charged with selecting cities in which to locate Federal Reserve Banks, under terms of the new Federal Reserve Act. Their first hearings were held in New York City (here, at the N. Y. Customs House) and in Boston. The New York hearings opened on Monday, January 5, 1914. Story in the New York Times, January 7, 1914 (other related stories preceded it): query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9901E... William Gibbs McAdoo, on Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4732557037/in/photostream/]

I don't think that's the USS Michigan. She had two funnels, and main armament in 4 turrets. Instead, I believe this is a battleship of the Virginia class of predreadnought battleships, based on the 3 funnels and double-story gun turrets. Also, the ship on the right looks like a French cruiser, based on the disposition of the funnels, and shape of the turrets. USS Michigan: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Michigan_(BB-27) Virginia class: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_class_battleship
After further research, the French cruiser at right appears to be from the Gueydon class: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gueydon_class_cruiser

definitely, the 3 funnels, the cranes, and the turret shape eliminate any other class.  All 5 from the class served at Veracruz, so it would be hard to say which it was,

USS Michigan definitely was at Vera Cruz in April-June, 1914. The Michigan's presence there could have caused confusion that led the Bain News Agency to mis-identify the ship in the photo.

Aside from the fact that USS Michigan only had 2 funnels, and the ship in this photo has 3, also note the shape of the cranes for the ship's boats. This ship has curved ones, while the Michigan had straight ones. I'm 99% certain this is not USS Michigan in the photo.

that's because she is the SS Havana, probably after a hard crossing www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-civil/civsh-h/havana.htm you can see her on the schedules in 1917 query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=980CE1DF1538EE... Launched in 1906, SS Havana was a passenger steamer for the Ward Line on the New York–Havana route from 1907 to 1917. Before being purchased by the Navy, the ship briefly served as United States Army transport ship USAT Havana and was in the first United States convoy of ships to sail for France during World War I. In her Navy career, Comfort made three transatlantic voyages, bringing home over 1,100 men from European ports. Comfort was placed in reserve in September 1919, decommissioned in 1921, and sold in April 1925.

My great grandparents and my granduncle used this ship for several crossings between Havana and New York City. Here is the manifest for Eva Ariel Lattin (1892-1939) and Anthony LeRoy Winblad (1912-1970), from my family, returning from Cuba to New York City on July 7, 1915

Anita Calvert Bourgeoise, St. Louis-based editor and publisher of The Invincible, which sounds like a comic book but was actually a women's magazine of "history and biography," by also patriotic poems, essays, and genealogical items. Looks like it only published in 1913.

I started a Wikipedia entry for her: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anita_Calvert_Lebourgeoise She was born in October 8, 1879 in Missouri as Anita Calvert, her mother's maiden name was Jones. She married Adolph Lebourgeois, and died on March 18, 1940 in Los Angeles.

Pince-nez type eyeglasses were the most popular eyewear in the USA, Canada and much of Europe during the period 1885 to 1920. A pince-nez had no arms or temples and clipped on the bridge of the nose. It was held in place by either spring powered nose guard grips in the fingerpiece type or a spring bridge with nose guard grips in the hoopspring or C bridge type. Properly fitted, a pince-nez remained securely attached to the bridge of the nose at all times and was very comfortable even during full time wear. Eyeglasses (pince-nez) and spectacles (glasses with temples) : were unisex then. The terms eyeglasses and spectacles had distinct meanings. The rimless type was the most popular and stylish for all ages. For soldiers,it was great for wear under a gas mask or goggles and army officials stated the a pince-nez was the ideal eyewear. 
See Pince-nez Renaissance blog/site the only place on the web or anywhere for very detailed,accurate info re: pince-nez.Click on table of contents. Many of the photos can be enlarged by clicking on them.
There was an AJ Collett who was Electrical Engineer for the Union Pacific Railroad, from Nebraska; resigned in 1914.

A. J. Collett resigned from his engineering post with the Union Pacific Railroad, to become Director of Public Works for the Dominican Republic, during the U. S. intervention in Santo Domingo. Collett's appointment came at the time of the removal, apparently for political reasons, of W. W. Russell, the American Minister to the D. R., and his replacement with a political crony of William Jennings Bryan, Secretary of State in the Woodrow Wilson administration. At this time, U. S. officials had control of administative appointments in Santo Domingo, and apparently discovered ways to turn them to pecuniary advantage. A. J. Collett was a beneficiary. "Every member of the American side of the Dominican customs force but one . . . has been removed and replaced by appintments of the new administration. With John L. Mann, a veteran in the service, ousted as Director of Public Works, Secretary of State Bryan has now suggested to the Dominican Government as successor to the salary of $6,000 the name of A. J. Collett of Mr. Bryan's own state of Nebraska, son-in-law of his old political crony, Mayor "Jim" Dahlman of Omaha. "The Dominican Government has not yet indicated its assent to the nomination of Mr. Collett, and it is known that it resents what it considers an application of the American spoils system with salaries paid by Santo Domingo." ---Story in the New York Times, December 12, 1913. The full story, "Bryan Defends Minister Sullivan," is here: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9E05E...
I did a little research in the World War I draft registration and started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin_John_Collett

A Newport socialite named Miss Edith Mortimer married Count Mario di Zoppola, an Itaiian aviator, in 1919, at her parents' country home in Wheatley Hills.  Her mother was Eleanor Roosevelt's aunt.  The Count and Countess di Zoppola divorced at Reno in 1929.   In 1937, Cole Porter was badly injured while riding at Edith di Zoppola's Oyster Bay estate.

I tagged all the Italian photochromes with their publication dates. They're mostly interpolated from two sources:
- "Voyage en couleur / Farbige Reise / Travel in colour" by Arqué from 2009 (which shows photochroms from all over the world, including those by the Detroit Publishing Co.), and
- "Deutschland um die Jahrhundertwende" from 1990 (which covers only German photochroms but gives publication dates by month and year)
and should be taken as approximate only. Both books contain very enlightening essays by Swiss lithographer Bruno Weber and of course many beautiful photochroms. Thanks to the Library of Congress for making them available digitally!
